But first actually we have to talk about how to actually define the diet because there's a lot of different ideas about what it is and to me a ketogenic diet is one which causes the body to produce ketones okay so ketones are the little small chain carbons they're basically really small fatty acid molecules that are you the most common one is a but it's a few to rate so that's a four carbon molecule that's just like a fatty acid chain clipped and then it has a ketone group on it and to produce those you're basically going through series of beta oxidation which is to go back you're taking a fatty acid through the diet it's going through beta oxidation you're just clipping off carbon's two at a time and then those go through the crep cycle that made KTP. What happens to produce ketones is there's a lot more beta oxidation going on than there is crep cycle so those two carbon things are building up in the cell and then eventually when they reach a critical mass they're leaking out into the blood and then they can get into the urine and that's how people are measuring them through the urine strips and through the blood ketone meters and other tools through the breath that they might be using to indicate whether or not they're in or out of ketosis so a quick definition on that is the body's making more ketones than it would through a different style of eating and to put some numbers on it if you're looking at the blood ketone meter to usually use 0.3 if it's beta hydroxybutary or 0.5 if it's total ketones just because there are a few different kinds. Okay and I just ask what's the difference from ketones and what I hear in those commercials that say be aware of keto acid doses what's the difference between that? It's not that the ketones are a problem. It's that the liver's failing and these are an indicator of that liver failing so they're the marker that's saying hey there's a problem here we need some attention and it's kicking out these ketones because it's trying to provide enough energy to stay alive once it's become so insulin resistant that glucose can't get in there. I like to we'll move on to these two different kinds of ketogenic diet we have kind of a modern and a classical example. So ketogenic diet's been around for about a hundred years maybe longer used to treat epilepsy and it's originally what called a therapeutic ketogenic diet that's one that's restricting carbohydrate to a great degree in order to elicit very high levels of ketones and to really reduce body's reliance on glucose as a substrate which seems to be therapeutic for people with epilepsy and more recently that same style of therapeutic ketogenic diet has been used research for obesity, diabetes and other clinical conditions. Still using therapeutic very low like 20 to 50 grams max total carbohydrate intake per day. Yes per day. That is very restricted. And that's a lot of the pushback on it is that it is so restrictive people can ever stick to it but if you're a healthy person you don't need to restrict it that much and that's kind of the more modern idea of a ketogenic diet where people are measuring and again to go back to that definition ketogenic diet is one which the body's anachitoogenic state where you're producing more ketones than you would otherwise and to that point before we move on too far having higher ketones doesn't mean necessarily you're doing a better job or your or it's not a direct relationship to how you are consuming that diet is not an indicator of your performance on ketogenic diet or how closely you're sticking to that. That's how you stretch your quad. So your bridge position is the quad stretch position. So lift up to that position, hold that position. I have them hold for about 30 seconds, really focusing on two things. I'm holding up three fingers. So let me go with three things, even though I really focus on two. The two things I focus on, see if you get a stretch on the front of the thighs and clench your glutes. And the other thing is just control that breathing and try to stabilize your core so you're engaging the core while you're in that position. Now, we go from the bridge hold. I time all of these right now. So 30 seconds to repeating bridges for 30 seconds. Making sure they're not rolling their spine, not that that's wrong, but that's not the goal. I want you to practice on hinging at the hip and driving the hips up because that's what a squat looks like. That's what a deadlift looks like. That's what Roman chair, back in hip extension, look like what I don't want is to practice rolling the spine. And then we go and do weights. And we're not rolling the spine. And then I have them lower their butt down, pick their feet up off the table. So their hips are bent at 90, their knees are bent at 90. Their arms are straight up from the air pointed towards the ceiling and they do dead bugs. Really focusing. I don't do as much keeping a neutral spine. And I do include that. But a lot of times to engage their core more, I'll have them press their low back and down into the table to engage their core and protect them from going into an arch position. Now once they get better at that, then we can take them to a neutral position and see if they can stabilize their spine with a nice natural or neutral arch in it. But they have to keep their low back, press down hard, press down hard into the table. And then I go into a mobility series. I have them still lying on the table or on the floor and they do window wipers. Hips in these still bent at 90, 90. Their arms are completely out to the side and their legs go side to side. So it's spinal rotation, but you're moving from the lower extremity. Legs are going side to side, trying to keep your opposite shoulder down on the table. And then I also do tail wiggles so that is shifting now instead of going up and as it's flexion and extension in the spine, we're doing frontal plane lateral flexion in the spine. So side to side, whacking your tail, basically. And then open books. Because it's where all ready in a quadripet position. So taking one hand behind the head and just trying to rotate the spine open as much as possible, doing that on each side. Have you lie down now? So you're in a prone position, cobra push ups, pelvis stays on the floor. You extend your spine and now you're going to the spinal extension as you do a push up, pelvis is down, chest is up, looking up towards the ceiling and back down. If you have people with spinal stenosis, don't do this one. If you have people, they do it and they go, I feel a little pinch. Just get out of it. Run. And then you can maybe advance it by going back into a supine position, doing iron crosses, so kicking your right leg towards your left hand with your arms up to the side. And scorpions would be a prone position where you in reverse kick your right hand, to your right foot towards your left hand and vice versa. It's called the Overwhelmed or the Adboyter procrastinator, meaning that there's something out there that they feel is too big. They just literally don't know where to start. And because of that, they feel like there's just so much to do. They feel paralyzed when you're like, okay, well, let me help you. Here are some options. === FILE: Anatomy Overview of the Latissimus Dorsi [VejtQnLvCxM].txt ===

Hey y'all, this is Rick and Annie with NASM. We talk about the lats. So the latsismist dorsai, latsismist means widest dorsai means back. So it's a really wide muscle on your back. All right, so we're going to show it on Annie, join actions and planes and motion. It's kind of like going to underneath the arm. So it runs through the arm. It's a lot of people think the lats go around this way and they don't. So they go underneath the armpit. They go all the way down. I like you can even see the wrinkle in her shirt, right? Which goes along with the lats. So it's going to connect into the Theraco Lumbar Fashia. So it's this little diamond shape, kind of a fashile sheath right here. And that connects to a lot of things. It connects to the sacrum. It connects to the ilium, connects to the lumbar spine. So the lats have an effect on all of those areas and all the joints in between them. Let's go sagittal plane first. So watch me take up into flexion. See how we stretch that muscle out in flexion? So when we pull her into sagittal plane shoulder extension, you can see how this muscle will shorten, right? So we see that this muscle does concentrically. It does extension, but it decelerates flexion at the shoulder. Alright, so let's switch planes of motion. Let's go on the frontal plane. So frontal plane, she's going to go out this direction. So you can see how she's going into abduction. That's going to stretch out the muscle. And then ADduction is going to shorten the lats. So it does concentrically addduction, ADduction. Now let's look at another transversal. Let's look at transversal plane now. It doesn't really do this very well. So you see that horizontal abduction? === FILE: Balance Training OPT Model [3C400aFB53Y].txt ===

The National Academy of Sports Medicine's OPPT model uses an integrated progressive training system. This includes all aspects of fitness, including balance. Balance is divided up into balanced stabilization, balance strength, and balance power. Many times after an injury, the proprioception in a joint is diminished. Therefore, balance training can help to re-establish and reinforce that proprioception in the joint. Balance stabilization is primarily used in phase 1. Here are our goal list to maintain perfect form. We want to be sure they can maintain control of the arch, keep the knee in alignment, and keep the proper position of the hips. This could include exercises as simple as a single leg balance, and maybe a single leg balance with the reach with the opposite leg. Again, the goal is maintaining proper form. Here we want to challenge the client's balance threshold. So what we would do is take them to a position where they can barely maintain proper form. Maybe you asked them to come down into a third or maybe a half of a squat, which challenges them a little bit more. As we progress to phases 2, 3, and 4, we're going to use balance strength. Here we're going to focus more on that dynamic aspect of balance. So again, we're going to be on one leg, maintaining proper form, but we're moving through a range emotion. These exercises could be a single leg squat, maybe a single leg box step up. As we progress to phase 5, we're going to move to balance power. Here our goal is to focus on controlling that desoloration for the body on one leg. Our exercise is maybe a single leg hot or maybe a single leg box jump, where we hold that landing for 3 to 5 seconds. That 3 to 5 second hold allows us to control our form to be sure that we're reinforcing proper form.

On this episode, Wendy and I will talk about Achilles. What is it? How to maintain good health and things we can do to make sure that we stay away from injury. So I hope you like the episode everybody and like, follow, subscribe, download and let us know what you think. Take care and happy listening. I am Wendy Bats here with my co-host and friend, Ken Miller, Ken. How's it going? Great, Wendy. I'm good. I'm going to add a thing about that for say, how are you? I am doing excellence. This week we're actually going to talk about this really extremely important tendon that we have been hearing a lot about unfortunately on the news and one that's very vital for upright movements and basically any time our foot hits the ground, it's, it's placed an important role. We're going to talk about behind every step and the critical role that the Achilles tendon plays on that role and yeah, I'm ready to dive in, Ken, how about you? I am because I have a friend who has a special interest in this topic considering he just tore his Achilles. I mean, that's the unofficial situation with my buddy. But it's strong suspicion that that is the case. So he's going to be listening to this episode once if not twice or three times. So yeah, I don't know about you, Wendy, but I'm sure you've had clients. You've had patients, friends. No, no, I never had clients, by the way. But I know people who were my clients would not have been in that situation. Unfortunately, we've seen it a lot, especially in basketball this season, injuries that were one right after. Now, and of course, when we think about an Achilles tendon, especially in ruptured, someone tore their Achilles. So we want to talk about what the Achilles tendon is. It is basically that strong, fibrous band of connective tissue that connect your two key muscles. So your gastrocnemius and your soleus, which are your two, two calf muscles, that blinth and to this tendon that attaches to your heel bone. So they'll call it sometimes the calcaneal tendon because your heel bone is called your calcaneus. And oftentimes, when we have really tight calves, we don't have motion or heel bone, which is as if you kind of play around with your foot, your heel bone should move. And if it's very sticky or it doesn't move because it's very stiff, then there's a lot of like tendons and muscles and everything that's around that that when it gets locked down, can cause big time issues, especially when you're doing something that is requiring you to do this explosive repetitive motion and your body isn't prepared for that. So that's, unfortunately, why we're seeing more of these ruptures and tears. And I mean, you, and you mentioned what's above the heel bone or the calcaneus, right? It would be Achilles and as it relates to the calf muscles, you talked about the gastrocnemius soleus, but if you actually stream down, if you go downstream from the heel down to the forefoot, you also have those, those muscles under the foot, right, that make up the foot arch. So that's, that's the other part. So when you talk about tightness in the calf, just as important and really doesn't get as much attention through it all is also the foot muscles as well, just because of the connection through that heel bone. So that that tension is going to be shared both up your Achilles tendon as well as downward from the Achilles tendon. So I don't know when the if you've ever done anything towards paying attention to the foot, but that's, that's a spot that gets ignored quite a bit. So there is this muscle way too much information, but if you look at the bottom of your foot, there's that big tendon that's kind of right underneath the ball of your foot that goes underneath the medial arch that you're talking about, called reflex or halicus longus. On today's NASM CPT podcast with me, Rick Richie, I explore some big problems from the Big Tell. I share a story about friends who are working with a high profile MLB player whose hip issues seemingly stemmed from what was a Big Tell issue. I'll also talk about the windowless mechanism regarding how the Big Tell gets more rigid as the Big Tell goes into extension. And then finally, I take a little bit of time and I talk about increasing range of motion at the Big Tell and what are some of the ways that we can do that. And then finally, how can we build some strength in the toe muscles, Big Tell in particular? All right, make sure that you like, follow, subscribe, and leave a five-star review. Now, here's the episode Big Problems from the Big Tell. You're listening to the NASM CPT podcast with Rick Richie. Winner of the Share Care Emile Award for Social Storytelling and the official podcast of the National Academy of Sports Medicine. Y'all and welcome to the NASM CPT podcast. My name is Rick Richie. And today, I want to talk about the Big Problems that you can have due to your Big Tell. So let's get to start this conversation with this. The interesting story, so I have two friends, two colleagues, two people who worked with one big athlete. It was a baseball player. And this baseball player really talented, big money player, and just kept having issues with the hip. kept having issues with the hip. So they go through and they're practicing, y'all, what's their internal rotation, external rotation, what's your hip flexion, hip extension, let's look at your knees, let's look at your ankle, doorsy flexion, okay, working on doorsy flexion, what's your plan to our flexion, let's look at your, and they go through a B-duction, a B-duction, a B-duction, the hip, all of these things at the hip. Let's test your core stability, and we're going through core work. And then finally they go, okay, let's let's look at your Big Tell extension, and from the non-problematic side to the problematic side, there was significant difference in the Big Tell extension, or some people refer to doorsy flexion of the Big Tell. I don't like the word doorsy flexion, I'm going to soapbox this for a moment. When people say doorsy flexion of the Big Tell, it doesn't make any sense, because there's no flexion, when you look at the heel bone, and there's plantar flexion and doorsy flexion, there's actual, the heel bone extends, all right, the foot, the heel bone extends past the tibia, and the front of the foot does too. So on each side, there's actual flexion that takes place, whether you measure it on the posterior or the anterior side, because either way can be considered flexion extension, based off the movement, which is why it has its own words. However, the Big Tell does not do that, the Big Tell can flex the Big Tell can extend, and I understand why, and I would call it doorsy flexion, I just don't like the term, so I say extension of the Big Tell. So they go and look at the extension of the Big Tell, and they say, okay, well let's do some mobility work, and let's get your extension at the Big Tell, and let's work on it, and create mobility, and all of a sudden, the hip starts to do better, but why? Why does that happen? Well, especially a rotational athlete. So whether you're throwing punches or swinging a baseball bat, or you're swinging a tennis racket, where does this come from? Well, the thing is that if you can't rotate onto your Big Tell, because the Big Tell doesn't extend, you can't rotate onto it, because otherwise, if it doesn't extend or either on the side of the Big Tell, or you're at a point, which nobody's putting weight outside of ballet on a point in their Big Tell. So what they end up doing is just over rotating from the hips, and getting that end-range emotion, potentially leading to some pinching, potentially leading to some laboral tears. So there's a lot of potential that can build up, simply because you can't extend the Big Tell when you rotate. So it's a valuable thing to look at, and here's another really interesting thing. A lot of people have mobility issues at the Big Tell, but you look at the flexibility, they have very, very inflexible Big Tell muscles, the flexor howlickus longus, gets stretched when you go into toe extension, extends your howlickus longus, not Dorothy flexor and platter flexor. I'm just going to argue with other mechanics, biomechanics, mechanics, people when it comes to doersy and plant her flexor, the Big Tell extension of Big Tell, and look at it. Well, here's what happens. When you go into toe extension, it pulls on the planter app and neurosis which pulls the heels and the toes slightly closer together and that creates a rigid foot. One, I love and I have almost every single person that I train with do this every single day as we practice balance exercises and when you practice the balance exercise, you're going to try to go into a short foot which strengthens the intrinsic muscles in the foot, but I also have them push their big toe down into the ground. So, it gives a little bit of purchase and gives something to grab onto some strength in the foot to hold the rest of your body on balance up on because remember, if you have a rigid surface, then you have a stronger likelihood to stabilize than you do on a softer surface and if your foot is soft, then you're going to get a lot more wiggling and each time you wiggle, you have to have a counter wiggle above it in order to to stack these joints on top at each other. So, we're going to consider that, so creating the short foot single leg balance pressing the big toe down. And of course, you can do other big toe exercises that I like to have people even just put a band around their knees and I call them knee wiggles where your feet are pointed straight ahead and you're doing that thing where you're crisscrossing your hands and when your knees touch, you cross your hands back. You don't have to do the hand part, just do the knee wiggle part so that every time your knees go closer together, let's say your feeder hip-width apart pointed straight ahead, maybe shoulder width apart a little bit wider. As your feet lower down, you'll notice that the arch flat ends and as your knees go apart, that the arch increases. You're going to get much bigger arch and so for my flat foot, it freins out there. Getting an arch on the foot to a big wind no matter what. So it's not just this concentric shortening, but it is an e-centric link-fitting of the muscles as well. All right. So I'm lying on a floor and my feet are on a bench, but not really. My feet are hanging off the bench. The only thing on the bench is my big toe. My arm, my big toes. So I got both of my big toes. Even all of my small knees on there too. So just my toes on there and I'm going to plant your flex, I'm going to draw my big toe down into the bench. Nothing on my foot is on except for my toes and then as I'm lying down, I bridge up in my toes or just clinging on like a foot rock climber. Just holding on with my big toes as I lift my hips up into a bridge holding on tight strengthening the muscles in my feet. And that's one of the exercises I absolutely love to strengthen the muscles in the feet in the big toe because they get that big toe. There can be some issues with it. So we're going to increase mobility. We're going to increase strength and we're going to help increase function up the kinetic chain by doing so. All right y'all. Thanks for listening. If you want to reach out to me, you can hit me up on Instagram dr.ricritchie or email me, rick.ricie at nasm.org. Y'all keep inspiring people to fitness. Thanks for listening. And so as we start to recruit more and recruit more, the first two to six weeks, as we said in the very beginning, you might not see any gains in size, but you're actually having more gains internally. And when we can get everything to fire the right way, and then we start to load it, that's when you're truly going to build hypertrophy or size, and you're going to be able to have good joint mobility in order to fully execute that one rep max without compensation. === FILE: Building + Nutrition Habits and the Downside of Liquid Calories [X7H92CDnsFY].txt ===

In the last video, Kara talked about how to use the habit to create new, positive habits. In previous videos, we talked about the power of starting small land-building tiny habits. Now let's apply this to nutrition behavior. Drinking more water, for example. Simply telling a client to drink more water isn't too effective on its own, so a strategy like what I'll describe may help. Using the framework to discuss around building habits, let's see how we can shape this. Of course there are lots of times of day you can drink more water. But since it would be easiest to spread out and take throughout the day, one cue you could encourage here would be to have a glass of water immediately after waking up. So when I wake up, then I drink a glass of water. Yes, it can be that simple. To craving, then can be the feeling of drinking a glass of water before anything else. That feeling of what you're about first in the morning or the feeling of how that feels in your body when you first drink it. The response then is deciding how much to drink. If the goal is, let's say, drinking half their body weight announces each day. For example, well, then starting with an 8 ounce glass may be sufficient because you're going to spread it out throughout the day. Finally, the reward might be as simple as checking off a calendar that the client drank water or market an nutrition log or tracker. So these can be pretty simple. It really depends what the client would benefit from and this can be decided together. While this may seem rather straightforward, when stacked together with other positive habits, you can see how magic can start to happen. One of your client stacks together that simple habit of drinking 8 ounces of water each morning with a 5 or 10 minute morning walk afterwards. When they get back from their walk, then maybe to enjoy a piece of fruit and take their vitamins for example. Next thing we know, more and more positive habits are in place and they take permanent residence leading to the desired outcomes. So you can see how all these tiny habits can add up to equal big results. Now, keep in mind, all these habits wouldn't take place or shouldn't be suggested overnight. The beauty of tiny habits is that they happen over time and get stacked on top of each other once previous behaviors have been established. Now, it's important to consider this example. Many times clients really want to unlearn a negative habit and they might decide to swap in water for other liquid calories. It's a great idea nutritionally speaking because on average, people consume about 450 calories each day from liquid alone. And that can mean things like soft drinks, fruit drinks, alcohol, sports drinks, you name it. Those calories can add up pretty quickly. But it's not as simple as just adding in the water as the new positive choice in place of the others. Because let's face it. What we might install the virtues of choosing water as the main beverage of choice, many people are committed to their soft drinks, their sweet, sweet tea, or their craft IPA's. In cases where your clients have ingrained habits around choosing less healthy options, we need to start with unlearning the negative habits first. Check out the next video where Kara will walk you through this example. See you there.

So as we go into the second part of the continuum which Wendy will discuss that now we have muscles that are more of a relaxed state and now they're going to allow the other muscles on the opposing side of the body to do what they're normally supposed to do. And I have done with some of our youth athletes before. So overall, you want to think about strength training. You know, these programs can benefit children and pre-adolescence by improving not only their strength, but also their ability, balance, lipid profiles, fat-free mass and of course personal self-esteem. And research is shown that school-aged children should participate in at least 60 minutes of moderate to vigorous, you know, developmentally appropriate of course physical activity each day. So some of the primary concerns and that's what we want to cover regarding strength training specifically is the safety and its effectiveness. And with some of the research that's out there, you know, if a strength training program follows the recommended guidelines and the precautions and is safe and effective, it's fantastic for children. And there's no real minimal aid requirement for any type of participation, although children must be able to follow directions. They need to demonstrate adequate balance as well as appropriation, which generally occurs around the ages of seven and eight. And you know, of course, starting the program, you know, you obviously want to get medical clearance and a full exam done by a medical professional. Same as you would do with an adult. So, you know, even when we look at fitness, we want to set everybody up for success and have that positive encouragement because that will absolutely carry over to later in life when people have this negative connotation towards anything exercise or fitness related because not everyone is going to move as well or be as coordinated or as fit. And, you know, there's a lot of factors that go into that and we don't want that to be anything that is magnified. We want everyone to be successful. We want encouragement. I'm not sorry, I don't train muscle that train movements. So, getting that, you know, dialed in in a very early age is going to have great carryover for later in life. It was squats, bench, dead lips, things like that. And I know that affected my long-term movement later in life because I was really locking in patterns under load that I had to kind of change at once I learned these models. Even if someone's not so-called talented, we all know that that kind of runs along the continuum and people get better at their own race. But if they have that emotional buy-in, they will that emotional bond what you're doing with them with movements will go a long way into keeping them focused and involved for the long term. And you know, you know, you spoke about this earlier, you know, we really can be a huge influencer and these children's lives to whether they're going to really love whatever it is that you're doing with them or later on decide that this isn't for them for other reasons other than, you know, they're just not skilled at that particular thing that you're showing them. So for example, if it's a specific sport, you want to mode them because the more that they know about a sport, the more they're going to remember or the important points, that's a series for the performance as well as motor skill development. And I think that's crucial. I mean, if you're always saying, that's not right. Don't do this and everything's very negative, then it kind of get a negative thought about whatever it is that they're doing and then they're not going to want to do it any longer. So then they give up and quit, which is obviously what we don't want to happen considering our obesity, you know, numbers as well as just, you know, children lacking the excitement about playing sports and just becoming physically fit. Yeah, and I think you brought up, there's another good point on that slide and that is about specialization. And it very well may be the case that athletes aren't talented in certain sports, but if you, if you get them to love the idea of participating, they will find that their particular niche of sports that are sport or activity that works for them and they'll be able to thrive. Mm-hmm. And that really does kind of bring us into that next one about, you know, the difference is really between sports specialization as well as diversification, if you will. And so like let's take two steps back and let's talk about the difference. Like, you know, early sports, specialization can be defined as like the year rounds, like intensive training and a specific sport with the exclusion of their sport at any age. And then of course, on the other hand, when we're talking about sports diversification, you know, is to participate in a variety of activities through, you know, through an athletes life. And of course, what we've read and what we've seen, this helps develop like multilateral physical, social as well as physiological skills. And so, you know, when you're thinking about that, you want to think about some considerations and concerns for both, you know, so, you know, if you're thinking about, you know, the specific, you know, specialization, you know, and or for, you know, to, you know, make a shot, like really good at something we think that it's going to have to be structured practice and, you know, it's going to contain certain developmental components. And, you know, it's, it's basically working on one motor skill development for that specific, you know, specific sport. And so, therefore, they become very good in knowledge of what motivated in socialization in that one particular area, you know, but then, you know, you're going to have, you're going to have success if you do that, that particular sport. And they will achieve success in that sport setting, you know, including things like running and jumping and kicking and throwing and stuff. And if a child has an amateur, but if I should say, but if a child has an immature level, you know, a fundamental skill development, then they may attempt to play that organized sport, but the experience may not be as positive as someone who was developmentally ready to learn that sport, you know. So, so you want to think about that. And then when we think about this sport, diversification, you know, this can be thought of, again, as playing, you know, many sports. And, you know, Marty and I've talked about this, but this method exposes children to a magnitude of sports that focus on more playing than just practicing, if that makes sense. And it's going to provide an environment that's going to nurture a genuine love for a sport, so that it's productive and structured, you know. And then that way you can have a practice that may follow later on. And, you know, the belief behind the sport diversification is that the physical and cognitive abilities are going to develop quicker, you know, by playing multiple sports instead of just one because the potential of crossover from playing multiple sports. So, you know, for example, instead of just only developing hand-eye coordination as it pertains to hitting and throwing and baseball, you know, a child can be playing baseball and then also play soccer and then they're developing like foot and hand-eye coordination as well. So, I mean, those are some considerations to think about when your child is going into sports, do you want them to play one sport or else those sports? Okay, great point and Marty, do you have anything to add to that? So, when we think about core, core work would be doing many of the same movements that you just did in the strength, but you're doing them faster. So, for example, instead of doing a cable chop, and now it'd be doing maybe something like a wood chop throw with a med ball. When we think about balance, balance working phase five is typically going to involve hopping exercises or similar, you know, with, but this time you're hopping and then holding that to work on eccentric force reduction, and then the isometric control at a faster speed while on a single leg. So, for example, a multi-planar hop to a stabilization hold or traveling hops to a stabilization hold. And this is also, you know, when you're actually learning the model where people get kind of confused, because in balance, when you're looking at it, it says hop to a stabilization hold. So, when people hear the word stabilization, they automatically go to the, the plyo part of the stable is holding one. So, one thing to think about is, again, if you're new to this, and balance and phase one, there's no movement of the stance leg, then we add eccentric and eccentric motion of the stance legs, so something like a single leg squat. And then now we're still on one leg and we're adding the hop, and it's an explosive hop, and then do you own it? So, that's why that landing is so important. And so, plyo, when we're talking about plyos, the work in phase five is going to involve clients performing jumping, some out, now we're on two legs, but the jumping type movement with appropriate accepted drills done as quickly as they can control to really exploit this stretch shortening cycle, which is going to improve how they rapidly produce force later on. So, beginning of the core and the balance and the plyo exercises in this phase are similar to what you could do in the resistance training portion of your program. You can't omit these components in a session, however, I recommend and I think any of them does as well, doing some sort of core balance and plyo work as part of the movement prep sequence. And with that being said, they don't have to be power focused as Marty was saying, but instead they could be exercises that are more stable, like stabilization or strength focused to help prepare and get primed the body to what's going to happen later work out. So, that's kind of a short and skinny of the phase five of what they are. It could be emotional stress relief. It can help preserve muscle. But when done wrong, it can actually be counterproductive. So we're going to break down what my best strategies, tips, and tricks for everything you need to know about cardio for bodybuilders. Let's go ahead and get started. One thing I like to start with is a little bit of caffeine. You might want to avoid high amount of caffeine, but we're talking low amounts. So consider maybe 100 milligrams, for example. If we were to time that pre-cardio, that can help increase our fat oxidation, and also help increase endurance or performance. There's some really longstanding articles, and it'll sprite 2014 is one of those that breaks down the study of potential benefits of low dose caffeine, pre-cardio, or pre-indurance training. And again, it's best used strategically to based on your tolerance. So again, if you have adrenal issues or sensitivities, you might need to limit, or keep those early in the day. And for me, it's also it wakes me up a little bit in the morning. The next thing we'll talk about, let's go into cardio-intensity and duration. We get this question a lot and I'll probably add modalities to that as well because this can factor into the intensity, but I always get the question, coach, should I do lists, low intensity steady state, miss, which is moderate intensity, or should I do hit cardio, is there a difference? If so, when should I do what? It can be a little overwhelming, right? There's a lot of different strategies. If we look at it high level, thinking about low intensity steady state defined as being somewhere in that 60 to 70% of your heart rate max, right, to 20 minus your age and years, time 60 to 70%. You get to that heart rate range for low intensity. This is gonna help promote fat oxidation without excessive fatigue. Now, if you are a very heavily muscle body builder, which I believe most body builders, that's the goal, right? We wanna carry as much lean muscles possible. When we're already in that state, the biggest concern is, again, muscle capitalism where we're starting to break down and we know acids from muscle tissue and converted into glucose as fuel. We don't want this especially when we're in a highly sensitive, fasted state. So, low intensity steady state or moderate intensity steady state cardio tends to be a little more favorable if we're in a fasted state early in the morning. This helps to mitigate super high spikes in cortisol, right? That's going to be in adrenal response, which, again, is a cat about hormone. So, we don't want that happening. Now, this or Miss Cardio tends to utilize about 90% fat as the fuel source, right? The oxidation source versus, let's take hit or weight training, right? Very similar impacts to your central nervous system. If we took hit training, that's using about 90% glucose and ATP as the fuel source. So, we wanna get strategic on what we're leveraging each of these. The benefit of hit would be higher amounts of total calories burn per minute, right? You might burn in one hour session and if you did hit cardio, which is a lot of cardio, by the way, one hour of hit might give you, let's say, 700, 800 calorie expenditure on that particular modality and you might only get 500 calorie expenditure doing lists or miss cardio on that same modality. But, if you look at the percentage split again, it's gonna be heavily heavily shifted towards body fat while preserving more of that muscle mass when you're doing lower to moderate intensity cardio. So, that's the main thing that we look for. In general, guidelines where we're talking about intensity duration of lists or miss, I would recommend typically 30 to 60 minutes at that 60 to 70% heart rate max. That's gonna again promote more fat loss without excessive fatigue or excessive strain on your adrenals. Whereas, hit might be better utilized later in the day. So, let's say, post meal one, maybe it's post workout, assuming it's not after, let's say a really hard leg day. If your goal is to maximize your leg development. But, when we're in a cutting phase and you need to get more cardio in, hit can actually save you some time as well. So, if we are very limited on time, you've only got 15 to 25 minutes to spend towards cardio. You might want to consider hit in that scenario because we can get a higher amount of calorie loss. So, generally, I like to do my list or miss cardio. That can be anywhere from three up to six or seven times a week for those shorter, we'll call it more reasonable intervals 30 to 60 minutes. However, when we're talking hit, I like to minimize that, especially when you're already training four to six times a week. With weights, I like to minimize hit to 15 to 25 minutes, one to three times a week and strategically after a meal or post workout. Hit cardio is also gonna help improve your VO2 max and calorie expenditure. But again, it carries a cost which is going to be some disruptions to your recovery curve. So, you don't want to time, you're, let's take your lagging body part, right? We need to bring the glutes up significantly, right? We need to develop a lot more muscle density there. So, we might have more food, more calories on that day. We might train lower rep range, right, lower volumes, but heavier weights. And then we need that recovery with nutrition, sleep, hydration. If you're adding in a lot of hit cardio after training that lagging muscle group, you're disrupting that recovery curve and it can actually be counterproductive. You might get some weight loss but you're also not developing the muscle that you're trying to develop. So, just keep that in mind and try to space those out on days that you're not training, you know, that lagging muscle group. Purityization, so early in prep, we like to think about doing a mix of hit and list, right? And we might mix those up again, one to three times a week hit and then the rest being list or moderate intensity. But then later in prep, especially as you get into that two, three, four week out window from a show and you're already near stage condition at this point, we wanna start to reduce fatigue. In order to do that, I like to shift some of that cardio back to low or moderate intensity. This is gonna help manage your cortisol. It's gonna also help reduce some of that joint stress. And we'll talk about modalities again that are more favorable if you're having joint stress and inflammation versus, you know, just running your body into the ground with high-emotic cardio, high impact all the time. One cardio hack is to think of cardio-like weight training, right? Volume, intensity, and frequency need to be managed, not just always cranked up. So, it kind of absinit flows, right? We start to tie training, increase things up, throughout the course of a prep. But then once we peak that out, we've now achieved their stage conditioning or we're approaching over reach and burnout, then we start to pull back. By over reach and burnout, what do we mean? When we're talking about cardio specifically, some key indicators that I would look for on prep. If an athlete is doing, let's say, two to four weeks apart, they're doing body composition scans in body or dexa. And we get two or three data points in a row where we see skeletal muscle mass decline, right? This is a very clear signal. It could be cardio-related, it could be recovery-related or combination, could be nutrition-related, and when we're looking at cardio, the first thing I do is review what's our total volume, are we doing 250 minutes per week, are we doing 500 minutes per week? Is it lists or is it hits cardio? What is the timing? Is it fasted or is it post-meal one or later in the day? And this is where you can really get surgical with the cardio. And again, it's not just cranking it up. It's about strategically periodizing the cardio in a way that helps give the benefits of cardio, like nutrient partitioning and fat loss, and cardiovascular improvements, emotional improvements, right, destressing without risking burning muscle tissue. And that's a very fine balance. So monitor those biomarkers, other good ones for me are HRV and resting heart rate. So heart rate variability, especially overnight, we want to see that stable or if anything, we'd love to improve it, right? We'd love to see that high in trending upwards over time. If we start to notice it declining, or we start to notice resting heart rate, starting to creep up over time, to get indicator we might need to rethink our cardio schedule to allow for more recovery. So a good segue there, right? We talked about some of the different types of hits versus list cardio and some of the precarious supplementation. Let's talk about fasted versus evening cardio a little bit more in depth, right? Fasted cardio, again, increases the reliance on fat oxidation. So about 90% or so, especially if we're doing low to moderate intensity. You know, even yo-him buying, if we think about that supplement, we mentioned earlier is going to be more productive in that fasted state, right? When we're talking about lipoluses and these things, we're setting ourselves up to burn more fat when we are in that fasted state, but we don't want to overdo it to the point where we're breaking down muscle. And again, the con of doing cardio in that fasted state is the higher cortisol. Cortisol not only catabolizes muscle, but cortisol actually stores visceral fat. So example, if you have high cortisol late in the evening overnight, for one, it's going to be annoying because it will disrupt your diurnal patterns and your sleep. But it can also increase belly fat storage or visceral fat. So if we're doing overdoing the fasted cardio to the extent that we're now in this kind of fighter flight, right, our sympathetic nervous system's getting too taxed, we get the higher cortisol, higher muscle, catabolism, and all of the things we don't want as a bodybuilder on prep. Another article that you guys can cite there is Harowitz, and that's a 1999 article. Again, if you want to research and go a little bit deeper on why these things happen in the body, it's actually really fascinating stuff. So we touched on fasted cardio. Let's talk about the difference when we go back to our evening cardio. And I say evening, but honestly, this could be anytime after you have food in your system. So we're just talking about fasted state versus non-fasted state. The evening or non-fasted cardio, one of the pros is that glycogen is already partially replenished. Cortisol is lower later in the day and after food. The con would be high intensity cardio or hit too close to bedtime may impair sleep. So again, a hit cardio is going to have a similar effect in your CNS central nervous system as heavy weight training right before bed. So if you are noticing some sleep disruption there, you might want to rethink the timing of your cardio. And sometimes it's inevitable. You might have a job where you're working all day long. Maybe you've got kids and responsibilities and you're not able to work out until the evening time, maybe you don't have cardio choices at home, so you have to do it. Post workout at the gym in the evening. And this is a good scenario where you might have to get a little bit creative on how we structure that cardio, so that it's not disrupting or interfering with your sleep and ultimately your recovery and performance. One cardio hack there too is use fasted cardio in moderation, especially deep in the prep. For off season or recovery days, evening cardio is actually left less stressful. If you are post show, you're reversing out, you're trying to restore your hormone access, right? HPG and man, HPO, HPA and females. We're trying to restore this hormone access. And if we're slamming the body again with six days of fasted cardio for 45 minutes, that's really causing further hormone suppression. So we want to start to pull back on some of that. This is where less actually yields more results. And we want to allow our journals and our central nervous system to recover better. So calories come back up. To maintenance, we pull back some of those inputs from cardio and training and the hormone access start to restore themselves. So just keep that in mind. It can be very useful. The other reason or way that I use it even in lifestyle, clients or for off season is for the nutrient partitioning benefits. And what I mean by that is, in fact, I think we did a full episode on this recently, but what I mean by nutrient partitioning is the way that our body utilizes those macro nutrition, that macro nutrition. Are we storing it as excess energy? Are we driving glycogen to the muscles? Are amino acids being converted into the muscles throughout the protein synthesis, mechanism. Versus, if we do no cardio, we're not really getting circulation. We're not inducing any nutrient partitioning. Chances are we're probably going to store a lot of those calories as excess body fat or energy. That is just energy. So we want to be in control of that. And one risk, again, with too much cardio similar to doing excessive amounts of fat to cardio, if we do just too much cardio in general, we do risk muscle catapulism. And it can also come down to not just frequency throughout the week, but the duration of the session. I have seen athletes that have done 90 minute sessions of cardio multiple times a week. And that's too much, right? Similar to being in the gym, pumping iron for two to three hours at a time, it's too much and actually becomes counterproductive. So not only do you get like, if we were to graph this out, but diminishing returns, but you actually get it to climb where it's now burning muscle tissue, which is defeating the purpose, right? And if you lose, think about this on prep. If you lose five pounds on the scale, you might be excited. === FILE: Conscious VS Unconscious Decisions [kvjbT7Lhlyg].txt ===

Welcome back. When we think about the habits most of us have, well, many of them are well established. Every day you make choices that you don't have to consider or think about. You simply do them. And thank goodness because we all be exhausted before we ever left the house. If we had to consider everything that we need to do. It's great when our habits work for us and help us live the lives we desire from the simple choice of remembering to shower and brush our teeth so that people want to be around us to more complex decisions like deciding to make the time to study and stay current on continuing education. But what about the habits that don't align with what we want to achieve? What about your client who really wants to lose weight and is consistently training to make that happen? But tells you that she just can't stop late night snacking on chips. Or what about the athlete who says they're committed to improving their performance? But then keeps on telling you about grabbing drinks with friends several nights a week. Reminding our clients and for being honest, even ourselves, how these choices impact our ability to reach our goals is an effective. We can't just tell them what to do. Many times we already know that these things are working against us. We know what we should be doing. Instead, we have to learn how to unwire the habit and rewire a new one to create changes that support our goals and that will last. And that takes conscious and repeated effort. The interesting thing about our brains is that they really like to be efficient. Your brain wants to take any action that you repeatedly do over and over and over again and move it into a habit. Because when it does that, it actually requires less effort to process and perform the behavior. It's been estimated that 43% of the decisions and behaviors that we do each and every day or habitual. Many we do the same things over and over and over again and in the same way. That's great when that works for us, right? And we're making good decisions, but not so good when we work against us. You see, when a habit is formed, the brain actually stops participating fully in the decision-making process. And instead, it turns it over to our subconscious. Now it's been estimated that our subconscious part of our brain can run the show for as much as 95% of the choices we make each and every day. This unconscious part of the brain, which is also referred to as the automatic, the fast brain or even system one, that part of the brain really helps us preserve mental effort. And it saves it for the critical thinking and problem-solving that the brain really wants to focus on. So, the fast brain is the one that steps in and makes a fast decision quickly. And it usually makes that decision based on our own experience, maybe on emotion or even impulsivity. It's the one that when you feel a surge of stress at the end of a long, hard day, declares, man, I need a drink. The conscious part of the brain, however, is which is known as the slow brain or system two, that's much more rational and logical. This part of the brain considers the pros and cons of any situation. It will consider the potential long-term consequences and what even connect our current choice to our long-term goals. The slow part of the brain is the one that you can plan on to help you decide how to handle that stressful situation. So when you want to turn to a drink, what might you choose to do instead? So it really prepares us in advance. So which one wins? It depends on what system you're using in the moment the decision is made. Now of course, there are ways to move toward more conscious awareness of the choices we're making and why we're making them. And how to make it less likely that our fast brain is going to rule the show. We'll talk more about that in the next video that describes the habit loop. And we can see how habits are formed. I'll see you there.

So let's talk about our anterior tibialis, our posterior tibialis, you know, those relatively smaller muscles that have to work for prolonged periods of time. So they have to work for long periods of time. And if they get fatigued and they don't do their job. Now again, muscles don't just completely shut off. But they're going to drop in their amount of work that they can do when they don't have that endurance and they can't fire properly or optimally. So now the sudden, you know, when you look at the rotator cuff, it's a stabilization and endurance structure. It has to work for a prolonged periods of time. So that's where, you know, why we have those acute variables exactly set that way where it could be two to three sets if needed of 12 to 20 reps because we really have to build the endurance. Just like, you know, moving up when we move out of corrective and we go into true stabilization endurance training, again, it's an advanced version. In a sense, if you want to look at that way, that's why we do planks and bridges. We're still working on all those little muscles to be able to create your foundation, right? I just like, you have to have that stability and support throughout your entire body. So corrective, you're just identifying a couple of weak links and bringing them back up to speed so then you can progress through the model. So it's just like any time we, you know, we focus on it, we describe it when you build your house. You better have a really solid foundation and a solid foundation, a human movement is the ability to stabilize all the joints for prolonged periods of time in ideal posture without allowing them to get fatigued during the activities that you want to participate in. Okay, perfect. And now let's talk about inter muscular inter muscular coordination and why that's important for how that should, how integration influences that. So the way I've always described it is I don't train muscles. I train movements. Now we just talked about intra muscle coordination and we're talking about trying to isolate a muscle, but you're still doing a movement, whether it's door to flexion, plan or flexion. Just the movement is much more simplified and it might be one joint moving in a very methodical manner where when we look at what Wendy talked about with inter muscular coordination, she's getting, she was I'm getting multiple joints to move in a sequence, right? Now I might describe the exercise to somebody as, oh, we're going to train and I put in the muscle, but I know that there's a generally speaking multiple joints that have to move in a sequence and fire properly in the right time to maximize the movement efficiency. And as I said at the beginning is I might still move in a similar pattern, but if I'm not getting the muscles to fire in the right sequence and also at the right ratios, then when I move, that's where you see these compensations. And we've already talked about what happens when we get these compensations and we allow those to continue to happen. So that's why we start with the intra muscular coordination because if you can't control individual joints, it's going to be real hard for you to control multiple joints together. We had more of one and then it was formally in Olympics for in 1920. So they had a one-handed clean-user, they had one hand snatched and then they had the two handed versions as well. I don't have that specific information. But in from 1928 to 1972, they had three primary lifts. There was a clean and press which if you've ever seen people been really far backward, I've seen that's the clean so they would pick the bar up, they did it to their shoulders and then they would push it over head and then they had the snatched and then the clean and jerk. In 1972, they dropped the clean and press and so we were left with a two primary lifts that we now hear about a lot, that's the clean and jerk in the snatch. So in the snatch there's a there's a typically a wider grip, slightly different starting position when you're coming from the floor and then you'll go from the ground and you'll come all the way up overhead in one one movement. The clean and jerk, you'll see in the bottom picture they'll rack it to the shoulder and then they'll stand up with that weight depending on how you do it and then from there they'll do a jerk which is more of an explosive district fires a knee-bain and then it's a dipping under the bar and and pressing it overhead and that's the difference. What this assessment flow is and how we use this to the benefit of our clients? Absolutely. So in the assessment flow or any time we're doing assessments we need to have some sort of a process, some sort of a systematic process we call it here an assessment flow and just the word there. I want you to think of this as we're going from A to B to C or 1 to 2 to 3 and we're always using the information from one assessment or one test to inform the next assessment and the next and what we're really trying to do here is we want to value the clients time. They're paying by the hour. We can break that down and by the minute and by the second. They're paying for every minute so we don't want to take them through a barrage of test or assessments is not actually going to inform our program. So that's the reason we have the flow here. So the first thing we're going to do is intake. We need to know about their medical history. We need to know their goals. I think a lot of times whenever we're thinking about corrective exercise we get we get lost thinking that well our goal is to improve movement quality but that's usually a secondary or in some cases it's even a tertiary goal in the eyes of the client. They have something else they want to accomplish. They need to take that information in so we can we can integrate it into our program if they want to lose weight. We're going to design our programs in a manner that's going to help enhance calorie-bearing potential. So we take the client intake and after that we're just going to take a quick look at it. Like the other day their posture is typically a representation of their habits. So we're just going to take a look at their static posture. However if they have core posture when they present statically it doesn't always mean that they're going to move poorly. So then we're going to take them into the transitional assessments or the the overhead squat assessment. And here's where we start to get a little bit more picky or a little bit more detailed if you will. If we see compensations in the overhead squat assessment we're then going to move to our two modifications which we'll discuss in here a little bit today. One modification is going to be elevating the heels the other modifications is going to be placing the hands on the hips and we're going to use that to direct our guide our focus so that will help us identify what a root cause may be to their movement impairment. If we get from that overhead squat assessment if we see the compensations and we get valuable information we can design a program that could be as far as we go with the assessment process. Some clients from there we could go right into designing a program or we could skip down to those mobility assessment which is going to help us confirm what we see in the movement and also give us a more subjective data. So we can take a look at how they're moving the range of motion and then we can come back and retest that. However if they do well in the overhead squat assessment then we're going to reduce the base of support and change some things up by taking them to a single x squat assessment or a split squat assessment. Again if we see the compensations here that may be all we need to design a wonderful program or if they do well then we can take them a step further we can get to the dynamic assessments. These are going to be a bit more complex. A lot of times we're looking at more eccentric control or reduced base of support with these or and we can do a loaded assessment which we'll talk a little bit about today as well. Then again there we use an information to come back to mobility assessments if we need it and then we're going to take all the information and design our corrective program. your back and just bring your leg straight back so with this I always when I was talking to my clients you know they're like but my hamstrings always feel tight and I'm like okay how long have you been stretching for for years and again my sarcasm is well what's the definition of insanity doing the same thing over and over again expecting a different result so if you've always been stretching your hamstrings and they're not getting better maybe that's not the problem so when somebody has an anterior pelvic tilt or an excessive forward lean their hamstrings actually in a lengthen position so the central nervous system figures that out and is like okay you're going to pull me on this massive amount of stretch I'm just going to lock up in a lengthen position because if you go any further I'm likely to tear now we could go through all the other things that happen with that what's going on with the glutes and all that but that's why you see so many hamstring injuries from people who are runners or sprinters because they keep stretching them which it basically is pulling them apart and there's a lot of trauma to the to the muscle fiber in that as well then they don't ever focus on their hip flexors and the glutes and then they run hamstrings in a weak in position and it tears and then most people if you're watching professional sports on TV they're like oh they must not stretch their hamstrings enough and it's this crazy cycle continues so when something feels tight take that into account but don't make any judgments until you do an assessment because you're probably going So let me try to take everybody through a little story. That's on good. Okay. Yeah, I can't well, so like, well, you know, as we know too, you know, when it comes to like rehabilitation, it can be from any, you know, healthcare practitioner. Well, in the 80s and 90s, we were very diagnostic and joint specific. And I'm going to kind of take everyone through the story so we can see where we've evolved to this model and also how it applies to the new and updated corrective exercise specialist material. So, so kind of going back to the story. So using the 80s and 90s, you know, the the orthopedic surgeon or the doctor would diagnose and they would give us a specific joint. So we would focus on the primary area of impairment. And then that's all we would do. We would not consider regional or remote areas and how they affected that one area. So for example, if I was seeing somebody with a knee injury and the other day as we would just focus on the knee, we wouldn't look at the interdependence of how the knee pain affects the hip or if we had decreased mobility at the hip, how would that feed into the impairment at the knee, okay? Or, just to lay it through the ankles. So back in 2007, there was a group of really good scholarly physical therapists who came out with this regional independent model. And they published a paper saying, hey, look, you know, we're so monocular looking at the primary source of impairment. We have to consider remote regions above and below as we are examining and as we are treating clients or patients. And so this model took fire back in 2007. And the article is typically called, you know, by Wainer. Rob Wainer is a really good, amazing physical therapist researcher. And his group put this out in a cot fire because we a lot of us practicing physical therapists and even fitness professionals, we've always looked at the whole body, right? And any SM really promotes that through the observational analysis of the kinetic chain, right? Okay? And we looked at it with the kinetic checkpoints. So we've always done that, but in 2007, it packaged nicely for us. And so then it kind of brought the language back and it started bringing a whole body of research started putting everything together. So then ever since 2007, we've had a good 15 years of research that have been looking at treating these remote areas and how it fixed the primary impairment. Okay? So for example, like if the fifth pro notices that, you know, someone is having some poor mobility or an impairment at the hip, we would want them to look at the knee and the ankle and see what is occurring from there. So the model as we progress and stuff has an, has an ableist to look at the whole body as one kinetic chain. And I thought, I thought it was interesting because even in, even in rehabilitation today, of course if someone comes in with like an injury or they've had surgery, we initially have to focus on that primary area of pain, but then we're also treating the rest of the body. Does that make sense? Right? Okay? Yeah. So this model has grown a lot because we've had some really good research that has shown this neurophysiological interdependence among our whole kinetic chain. Like for example, there's been many, many good quality studies that have shown that, you know, if you have like a, like, a chronic ankle instability, like from ankle sprains and stuff, that actually causes hip abductor weakness. Okay? Um, another example is we found out that if someone has like a tennis elbow, okay? Really simple, you know, that, that lateral upper condolitis. If we treat the neck, we can, we can, um, we can eliminate a lot of the symptoms in the elbow. Okay? So we're seeing that we're seeing that there's a lot of research coming out mainly in like the rehabilitation literature that's showing okay, you know, you first have to address the side of pain. Of course, we have to take care of the primary. But then you got to start treating the joints above and below with either mobility, neuroreeducation, you know, kind of getting that whole mobility stability concept going throughout the kinetic chain. And then, and that. And so, so we took, so when we created, um, you know, kind of started mapping out the new and updated corrective exercise specials material, we felt that this model has as grown over the years, was a perfect fit into that whole model approach. half and that was the only information they were given they were in counsel about what foods to eat they were told to change anything they were made any recommendation about foods to consume or any timings is between the weekday and the weekend and in research they've actually started to refer to this as social jet lag in that we know that jet lag comes about when people travel time zones and that leads to certain degree of symptoms because their body clock or their circadian clocks have shifted by a certain number of hours and so trying to readjust then leads to these certain symptoms of jet lag the same thing can happen if we can shift our sleep and wake timing which happens from during the week to the weekend people typically sleep in at the weekend they also go to bed later on a Friday and Saturday presuming we're talking about the person that's working it let's say a Monday to Friday 9 to 5 type job then that will be a typical change we see with those changes we also see the same with their food intake that their first meal of the day typically will shift maybe by a couple of hours and they'll also probably have their final meal or larger meals later in the evening so rather than having their typical dinner maybe at 5 pm or 6 pm they may wait and have a meal out with friends at 10 or 11 pm right which is not necessarily problematic because we want people to enjoy life but done consistently what that leads is this change in sleep and wait time this change in feeding times for these two days and that creates a shift in a circadian phase shift we call that when Monday rolls around then now someone is waking up with an alarm clock and having a meal earlier and so now you have this mismatch between what their body has just has been shifted to over the weekend so this is the idea of social jet lag and what this speaks to is that we have this interaction between the circadian component or the circadian clocks and our body but we also have these different pathways that we call nutrient sensing pathways so this collection of receptors and enzymes and hormones are all orchestrated to notice when certain nutrients come in probably the best example is one that would be quite familiar to you if we're talking about blood sugar control is that we know that insulin gets released when blood sugar goes up right so blood sugar or blood glucose increases then we release insulin insulin comes out attaches to an insulin receptor and gives a signal that essentially say we want to get some of this sugar or glucose from the blood into a cell therefore bringing around in higher amounts than usual so we have these ability to sense when nutrients have came into the body or not now what happens is we essentially can because of these things have an anticipatory effect built up that our body is designed to be able to anticipate when we're likely to eat so this is driven by habitual meal times let's say and when we match that up with when we're best able to handle meals again talking about the circadian rhythms then that can essentially be beneficial when there's a mismatch between those is when we can have problems a most obvious example of a mismatch between our feeding intake and our normal circadian rhythms would be someone who does shift work and then they're first going on shift work now they're having to eat during the middle of the night they're eating at a time when their body is not anticipating that that they've anticipated the earlier now our body is pretty good at adapting in some manner at least so when we sense this new intake And the ones we're going to cover today are power, agility, speed, and stamina. We know athletes utilize training programs to ensure that they achieve very specific results. Now what I like to say is in my house, I am not the cook. My wife is a far greater cook than I am. And guess what I got, she was very impressed with the way the dinner came out. And the reason I bring that up is in fitness and sports performance, there is the recipe to develop speed. We know the science. There's the recipe to develop power, agility and stamina. And if you follow those recipes, just like if you go through the different phases of training, that's your recipe. You follow it. You're going to get great outcomes. But if you don't follow, you start throwing a bunch of things in, like if I changed her recipe in the kitchen, it wouldn't have been what she asked me to do. And it could have maybe been better. But probably I wouldn't have gotten this good and desired of an outcome because I'm not trained to make those adjustments. So when you look at these pillars, whether you work with the world's greatest coaches, like we have any Olympics, when you follow your OPT evidence-based model, your recipe to achieve those adaptations are there. That's a training program. Exercise is when you see a bunch of things thrown together. And yes, it's human movement. Yes, you can accidentally improve some of these capacities. And then yes, you can burn calories and get leaner and things like that. But what if you follow the recipe more specifically? Yeah, you can't argue the game you got. But we could argue you might have gotten better games. Quicker, safer, more effectively. So we're not again, not asking you to have fun in your workouts, not get creative, and not make it enjoyable and challenging appropriately. Because here's the thing, we do need peer-reviewed research and we need to understand what makes that reliable. And here's the thing. When you read the comments on social media, everyone is an expert. Everyone's an expert. We've got experts that are all disagreeing with each other. So who is the legitimate expert? And I think we need to really understand what that is. How do I know who an expert is? Everyone in social media, they love to follow those that push back against the mainstream. And for what they themselves like to do already. So let me lean into something I'm already interested in. And I think there's a place for pushing back against standards and norms. But how much of those standards and norms are based in research and how much of those are simply tradition. Also I will point out that some people do get degrees not to learn necessarily, but to appear as an authority to pitch their own individual thoughts. And I think that is something that's scary, something to be aware of. And with all of that, let's get into it. Let's figure it out. So the first thing we need to talk about is what is peer reviewed research? We're going to question peer reviewed research. What does this mean? So let's get into it. Peer reviewed research is a rigorous vetting process which other experts in the same field evaluate an article that is submitted and they're going to evaluate it for accuracy, for validity, for methodology and originality before they publish it in a scholarly journal. All right, cool. So my peers do that. But your peers in research are different than your peers at the pub. Your peers in research are different than your homies that you're going to be dealing with. Your peers that do research are not people that you hang out with. They are peers because they are in your same group of experts. And here's the, all right, for as well, who's the peers? They are other experts in the field that you're submitting your research to. And that's why there's so many different research journals, a journal. So what's out for the journals? Journals. So here's the thing, infectious disease. There are people who research that, but they don't submit their content to the American Journal of Occupational Therapy. Because experts in occupational therapy are not experts to critically evaluate infectious diseases. Is there some crossover? Probably. There's some things that occupational therapists need to understand about infectious disease. Probably, yeah. But they're not experts in that field. So if you look at it similarly, we've got the journal of strength and conditioning. I, I, I, ascribe to that journal, I get those research studies. I get, I get the journals that come from there. And then you've got the physical therapy and rehabilitation journal. Now the physical therapy, real rehabilitation journal cannot evaluate. They can evaluate each other's content. Because is there crossover on that? Surely much more crossover there than infectious disease and occupational therapy. Strength and conditioning and physical therapy and rehabilitation. Is there crossover? Yes. Are they experts in each other's field? No, they're not even close to experts in each other's field. Unless there's an expert in both of those fields, which means they have advanced degrees and many years of study in that field. So what's the purpose of this? Well, I need to understand that the peers that I'm submitting my research to are very, very educated and not just the field that I'm submitting, but in research, in methodology, understanding validity.
