Are they the gold standard? Well, first of all, we got to identify what is an RTC, a randomized control trial. And so I'm going to read you an entire article. It's a very short, a couple paragraphs from Harrington and Locassio in 2018. The article is entitled, Randomized Control Trials. The gold standard for effectiveness research. Okay, well, that article clearly thinks that it is the gold standard. But let's get into it. Randomized control trials are CTs. I said RTCs earlier, RCTs are prospective studies that measure the effect of Venice of new interventions or treatments. Although no study is likely on its own to prove causality, sidebar. Research doesn't prove anything. Research creates correlations. So the proof cannot be identified from a study. So all they're trying to do is create correlations in something. They are trying to say based on this, this happened. Is that proof? No, that is an indication that something could be true. We can't say that it is proof. All right, so with that said, although no study is likely on its own to prove causality, randomization reduces bias and provides a rigorous tool to examine cause effect relationships between intervention and outcomes. This is because the act of randomization balances participant characteristics both observed and unobserved between the groups allowing attribution of any differences in outcome to study the intervention intervention. This is not possible with any other study, design, in designing the randomized controlled trial, researchers must carefully select population. Interventions must be compared and outcomes of interest. Once these are defined, the number of participants needed to reliably determine if a such a relationship exists is calculated as a power calculation. Participants are then recruited and randomly assigned. This is a randomized controlled trial. They're randomly assigned into either the intervention or comparison group. So one gets the intervention, one gets the comparison. So let's talk infectious disease. Intervention group, one gets the intervention, the new intervention, and the other would get standard treatment. And we compare the new intervention to the standard treatment. Is the new intervention better? Is it the same? Is it worse? And then sometimes you even have a control that doesn't have an intervention at all. It has a placebo and a placebo group may say, yes, I feel much better, but they only feel better because they think they got an intervention. That we need to see an intervention. We're going to use a control and we're going to blind them, not them personally. We don't, it would be awful. You did a great job. What we're going to do is, this is called a concealment or a blinded study. It's ensured and what they do is the people who are doing the research don't know which is the intervention, which is the troll. They just seek the outcomes. They submit it and then people identify, okay, well, who was in the control group, who was the outcome, what did the researchers identify with these individuals? And then you can say, oh, was any progress made? So randomized control trials are often blinded so that participants and doctors, nurses, researchers, they don't know which person is receiving the treatment and that minimizes further any more bias. They're going to say randomized control trials can be analyzed by the intention to treat analysis and there are other variations when it comes to intention, the treat that are less biased, but all randomized control trials should have a pre-specified primary outcome. I want my person to get better feel better, move better, get stronger, increase muscle mass. That's what we want to outcome to be, which intervention did that better. And then there should be registered with clinical trial database and they should have the appropriate ethical approvals. Trust me, the ethical approvals can be difficult to get through. There's a lot to jump through with that as well. Randomized control trials have their own drawbacks and that includes high cost in terms of time and money, problems with generalizing things, the participants that volunteer to participate, might not be represented in the population that you're trying to actually study and that you might have loss when it comes to follow up. So, is a randomized control trial the gold standard? It is the gold standard of research. Yes, however there are gold or standards. Those are systematic reviews and meta-analysis according to on and conk 2018. A systematic review collects all possible studies related to a given topic and design and reviews and analyzes their result. So, that could be qualitative or quantitative. We're going to take it all, we're going to review it and then we're going to put out the results of a lot of different studies on the same topic. Now, meta-analysis is a valid objective qualitative, sorry quantitative, version of research, is scientific method of analyzing and combining different results. Usually in order to attain a more reliable result, a meta-analysis is almost exclusively conducted of randomized control trials, which have a high level of evidence. Well, listen, if you need to have a good financial offense, you need to have a big shovel to scoop money in towards you. Then you need to also have a good financial defense. However, there are people that make a ton of money that spend their income and do not build any wealth. So it's the borrowing of money is relatively inexpensive. But there's some high interest debt. And you've got to pay off all of that high interest of debt debt. And then you have to avoid getting in any more of that high interest debt. Usually, that's the form of credit cards. And that's a conversation we're talking about. If you've got 20 something, 28% APR, annual percentage rate on your credit card, that's going to be really hard to get out of that debt. And you've got to pay more than the minimum amount. So you've got to not just cover the interest. You've got to start paying down principle. So interest decreases. Get out of that financial hole. Get rid of the debt that you owe. And then do your dentist not to dig that hole again. And so you need to have money, not just set aside. So you're taking care of that debt. But also just having some money set aside for emergencies. You've got an emergency fund. So when things pop up and things, you know, what do we have to help up? Then you've got to have something that supports you. So you don't go in debt again. So save some money, set it aside for emergencies. And then start paying off that high interest debt. And then when emergencies pop back up, do your best not to put it on credit card. Make sure that you've got that money set aside. So you can pay off anything that comes up. So you have to have a good defense. You have got to stop spending frivolously. And I'm going to tell you story about a person. I have a friend in New York City. Makes a lot of money as a personal trainer. Charges way more than I charge, per session as a personal trainer. I mean, it's astronomical. And he wanted to go into business with me and my partner at one point, but he didn't have any money. Why not? Why don't you not have any money? You make a ton of money. Now part of it is because you may charge a lot, but you don't actually train that much. But I said the relatively busy. And if you're charging those rates, you don't have to train that much. That's a ton of money to make. So later, I was talking to the same person. I said, you know, I asked if you put any money aside for retirement. And he said, no, he needs to buy a house for his mom first. Then I was like, does she not have a house? She doesn't know. She does have one, but I want to buy her a nice house. And this is an example of someone that makes a lot and spends a lot. They have a fancy New York City apartment. They have to nicest outfits. They have big spenders, but not a big saver at all. And if this person just spent $500 a month, $500 a month, that went into a brokerage account, a retirement account, a tax advantage to retirement account, it would not adversely affect his life at all. But it would be huge given enough time in the market. Because time in the market is more important than how much money you put in the market. For instance, if you put $10,000, and I listen, I'm not saying you need to do $10,000, because you can do with some of these companies, you can do pennies to invest. And then you just kept doing $500, and eventually that would be $10,000. But then also you have the compound interest, and you also have the additional $500 every month. Kevin, I will turn it over to you. What is HRB? So heart rate variability is essentially the measurement of variation in time intervals between heart beats. We use the EECG and believe that these heart beats were supposed to fall very consistently. But we now understand this is really only from a bird's eye view. When we zoom in at the level of milliseconds, there should actually be a lot of variability in these heart beats. Each time an individual breeds in, their heart rate should speed up a little bit, a little sympathetic activation. And when they breathe out, their heart rate should slow down. This is kind of term is called respiratory sinus arrhythmia. This allows us to assess that the chronic tug of war being played at the level of our sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems. Okay. So you unravel that in a couple of short sentences. There's a lot to unravel. I mean, you brought up the autonomic nervous system. So let's talk about what that system is and how that works to keep our bodies in balance. Certainly, the autonomic nervous system, I'm sure many of us have learned the basics of our sympathetic and our parasympathetic. But maybe not really how this applies to health and performance, know how to really implement this. Heart rate variability is a measurement of the autonomic nervous system, which controls or regulates processes, including our stress hormones, inflammatory processes, and even our immune system. So when it comes down to health and performance, this has relations across the board, largely in terms of optimizing sleep recovery and minimizing the risk of injury. Okay. And so let's talk a little bit about, I think we're going to get into that into in the next couple of slides. Let's talk about definitely how it's measured and how these differences in HRV heart rate variability are related to different health markers. As we could go to the next slide and get into that. Okay. Can you take us through this science and the use of HEEE, please? Certainly. Before we really dive into the research, I think it's important to note kind of what I'm meaning here when I say reduced in higher heart rate variability. There's not exactly a magic number that everybody should shoot for, and I know that this may be confusing, but higher is not always better. The majority of the research that we're going to talk about here relies on comparing an individual to their specific population. Whether this be their competitive population or more basic their age, gender, ethnicity, population. Okay. Do you have, I don't know, everything with science and measurements fall within a range. Do you have basic ranges that we can work that we work off of when we're assessing this? There are very general ranges, which is something that I tend to stay away from. The general would be 60 to 100 milliseconds when we look at the time domain, which will dive into a little later. I'll make that a little more clear. What we really focus on is understanding an individual's trend. We require a minimum of five day baseline with no intervention. We really want to objectively understand where they're starting from, and then you start to apply these interventions, training, nutrition, modifying their hydration habits, and really what we're looking for here is looking at changes in individual trend. Improvements mean our interventions are in fact working, whereas if we see a decrease, we have to look at compliance or possibly a dynamically adjusting our interventions. From a health perspective, heart rate variability has been correlated with about 90% of all preventable health conditions, things like obesity, diabetes, and even cardiovascular disease. So when it comes to setting goals for our health-focused clients, heart rate variability is really one of the most meaningful biomarkers that we should develop programs around, and really use as a reinforcement tool to show our clients progress and maintain their motivation. The biggest kind of uphill battle that I have here is educating the clients on the value of this metric. They've likely never even heard of this. We're trying to say, this little number is more important than your scale weight, BMI, and possibly even that blood pressure you're getting twice a year at your doctor's office, because you're collecting it when you're nervous. This population, what we really need to emphasize is fitness is not just about thin muscles, and so I thin waistline and big muscles. It's physical health, mental health, stress management, having enough energy to play with your kids after a long work day. These are basically aspects of fitness that can't be measured by that little number on the scale, but they can by things like heart rate variability. Okay, thank you for that explanation. As I'm looking at this slide, we talked about we're looking at how higher HRV is associated with cardiovascular fitness resilience and decreased risk of injury. Can you tell us what that higher HRV means per population? Because I know that it's higher isn't necessarily better as you told us in the very beginning, but what does that mean specific to a given population? So when we compare a well trained athlete versus say their sedentary counterpart, same age, same gender, same ethnicity, the well trained athlete tends to maintain a higher heart rate variability or greater value. We see this highest in the endurance athletic population. A lot of the research that we're seeing now shows a really strong correlation between any intervention that improves our body's ability to utilize oxygen is correlated with better heart rate variability measures. Okay, great. And then is this doctor, Kyle, do you have a comment? I do, and it's kind of a maybe a general comment. I hope I'm not interrupting you and interrupting your flow, but when we're talking about this, one of the things that I used, and I was first introduced to HRV, and I think we talked about this before, but it was maybe 2013, 2014, going back a few years before that. There was an interesting study that looked at elite swimmers. And it wasn't necessarily about HRV, but it used HRV as one of its measurements. And one of the things they found in these swimmers, that by tracking or measuring their HRV in the mornings, they found that those that were more dominated by that sympathetic nervous system, versus the Paris sympathetic, they were able to measure a spike or an increase in sympathetic nervous system dominance about a week before these swimmers were either injured, muscular injury or before they became sick. So I think that's one of those things too, looking at this, these, the chronic diseases and stuff are obviously incredibly impactful, but sometimes for the clients, I think if they could understand too on a kind of a shorter window, like making sure that we're regularly checking this HRV to make sure that we're maintaining that proper nervous system control, that can have also very, very quick effects on your overall training. That's what I wanted to say, Princess. Absolutely, so thank you, yes, we want to, and this is going to lead into the next set of slides. We're going to talk first about, or Kevin is going to talk about our methods of measurement, what the sorts of things we're looking for and how this is recorded, how we can take this information and use it for our benefits. So let's take a look at the next slides. All right, so the methods to actually collect heart rate variability can get rather complicated. I'm going to do my best to keep them pretty simple. The two methods that really are front line here include electric cardiography, ECG, right, putting these sensors all over our body during a stress test or at rest, or a photo-plathy smogography, or PPG. The gold standard, which we will see in a clinical setting, is ECG. This uses electrical impulses to detect these heartbeats, essentially just looking at these time variations in between heartbeats. The primary issue that we see in most commercial devices, you know, these wrist-worn wearables, is that most of them don't have very good ECG sensors in them. At Biostrap, we have a very unique approach to utilizing PPG. Using our wrist-worn device, we utilize dual wavelength LED in optical sensors. Basically, for red light, is able to really deeply penetrate the tissue, and we're able to actually assess volumetric changes in the arterial pulse, heart rate, heart rate variability. And then we pair this with red light and this allows us to estimate other measurements, including your oxygen saturation. A lot of the devices that we see out there on the market simply use green light. Green light, unfortunately, is not able to penetrate very deeply. And this is why many of us may have seen some research about these wearables, not being very accurate for darker skin tones, people with pattoos, or even people with poor circulation, or this data is even more meaningful. Okay, and what if so, we look at this, or let's take us behind the scenes, because I was looking at my, uh, I'm actually wearing my biostrap. And, and it was, it was calibrating, it was calibrating my data. So, I know we have a couple of wave forms here from an EKG, but what is the, what is the strap picking up on the back end of the, on the back end of the app, so to speak? So, what we're collecting here is what's called raw PPPG waveforms, which you really wouldn't be able to interpret, right? What we do is we run this through 29 unique parameters, and this allows us to one really create a very clean waveform, kind of like we see there in the middle picture. And then these parameters allow us to assess for confidence, right? We, we run it through this parameter. If it doesn't pass a confidence check, we're going to exclude this data. We don't want to build, you know, bad data into a clinically reliable system. So, each individual heart waveform is analyzed, and then this is how we're going to analyze these heartbeats, which brings us to that third graph, where we can see variation. This would be a very healthy heart rate variability. If they were all falling, if their heartbeat was as consistent as could be acting as a metronome, we would see a perfectly straight line. This is showing a lot of variability in between heart B intervals. Okay. And Kyle, do you have any questions about that? Any comments? I don't think I do. Okay. Awesome. So what we'll do is push an assessment while you're sleeping. We do attempt to collect the state of while you're awake as well. They're certain value there. But when we trend nocturnal data, we have high confidence that we're controlling everything that can be controlled in a natural environment. We utilize machine learning, which we're going to look at an individual trend that the green represents their normal zone. Anything that happens in that green zone, we frankly don't care too much about. When you look closer, there's a red dotted line above and below, and this represents statistically significant change at that individual level. When we see their heart rate variability drop below that red line, we should be alerted. We're going to get an automatic alert so we can intervene and modify a certain behavior. When there's a statistically positive change, when it goes above that red line, now we know what we've been doing is in fact working. We want to reinforce our client because most basic, you know, if we're trying to maintain a behavior, we really ought to make them feel really good about that. === FILE: Helping Clients Navigate Stress Eating [LRCC6aKk-kc].txt ===

Welcome back and today's world, Stress Eating is real. During times of stress, our body's crave simple carbohydrates and sugar. It's an easy, quick hit of comfort, but ultimately can derail healthy behaviors, cause weight gain, and lead to poor client adherence. So how do you help clients who struggle with excess stress and stress eating as their coping mechanism? What are helping them to eliminate the stressors altogether? You can help them with tools for stress management and also help them identify when they are turned into food as a coping mechanism. To do this, I want to introduce this concept using an acronym called Holt. Holt refers to a four-seable questions that you can ask to determine if your clients are physiologically hungry or psychologically hungry. The questions are, am I hungry, at the age, am I anxious, the A, am I lonely, the L, or am I tired, the T? You see, in only one of these situations, does the client really feel hunger? And all others, it's psychological hunger, and we might be turning to food to really help us distract or entertain ourselves. So to determine if I'm really hungry, I just simply ask myself, would I really help me choice that I normally love to eat a peeled me right now? And for me, that's usually, would grilled chicken and veggies a peeled me right now? And if the answer is no, we're then on pop-ably experiencing another emotion, and I'm really trying to run away from that feeling. Now if person is tired, research just shown that we actually try to eat ourselves awake. Studies have shown that we eat approximately 350 more calories per day when we're sleep deprived than one or not. So in any case, and only one of these situations does eating make sense. And all others really food is serving as an urge or craving. And if that's the case, you can use that strategy of urge serving and teach your clients to ride that urge wave until that feeling passes. Then again, if they still feel like maybe they want something in 15 to 20 minutes, they can use that help acronym again to determine what they might be experiencing. The more they practice the strategy, like discussed in the previous video, the more they practice riding out that urge wave, the more likely they are to unlearn that negative pattern of stress eating. Thanks for joining me.

=== FILE: Helping Clients Navigate the Snack Aisle [CvHgcF9HHj8].txt ===

Have you or your clients ever had a snack-sadent to me neither? The fact of the matter is we get a lot of calories from snacks alone. In fact, research shows that Americans eat about 25% of calories from snacks every single day. You heard that right? A quarter of all calories just from snacks. Now I'm actually not saying this is good, nor bad. The truth is it depends. You know what I mean by that? Well, it depends means there are a lot of variables around what, when and how to snack. What does snacks look like? How much of your clients eating both in volume and frequency? And why do we snack? Let's unpack this a bit more to provide real-life examples of what to look for along with some snack options and examples of actual foods. Now before we even get into that, the real question is what is a snack? Well, basically a snack is the eating occasion between traditional meals, which other find here as breakfast, lunch, and dinner. So snacking would be anything before between or after those traditional meals. Then we have to consider what is in a snack itself. As a general rule of thumb, snacks should be relatively small. Maybe a couple hundred calories or so depending on goals. And should I deal with some fiber, some protein, and some fat? Now that's not tremendously specific, and this isn't an attrition course either. So you can get a lot more in depth on this topic through articles on the NSM site, among other reputable sites as well. But that's a good general starting point. Remember protein, fiber, and fat for your snacks. Next, why do we even snack it all? Well, a recent survey found the number one reason is because people are hungry or thirsty. I could live with that. The second is craving something sweet. And the list goes on and on. But that's important information in terms of what you may suggest to a client. If they're craving something sweet, for example, a new suggestion, a handful of raw almonds, well your recommendation isn't going to stick, at least for a long. This goes back to working to understand a client's identity and how they see themselves. That may not be something that you glean from a simple conversation. But after working closely with them, it may be something you'll better understand. The snacking also fit with your client's desired outcomes. Now there are a lot of variables around this. What are their goals? What are those desired outcomes? But when you understand what the outcome goal is, of course, working through that with them, helping a client work on their process goals can include answering these questions. Why? What? How much? etc. To help them figure out the best plan to navigate the snack aisle. That's it for today. See you in the next video.

=== FILE: How To Build A Plate [BvElAC8tEGE].txt ===

Alright, so now we've touched on how habits are created and the power of tiny habits. Let's actually specifically look at some examples using nutrition and the way these clients can build their own plates to meet their needs. And or their sense of identity. First, when we think about a plate, it's important to stress the nutrition is not black and white. Clients want it to be and let's be honest, it will be so easy for us to simply give people those nutrition rules. Eat this, don't eat that. But there's much more nutrition than what to eat or not to eat. What if you're out with coworkers or friends? You're at a social event or it's a big holiday and you're surrounded by different foods and alcohol. All of these things can make it a challenge to continue to achieve what a clients are working towards. That said, let's simply look at what a plate could look like and to allow you to better talk to clients about their eating situation. So what we have here is a general plate. And now this recommendation is in specifically low-car, low-fat vegan, gluten-free or anything. It's a way to balance your plate that can meet the needs of most clients and allow for personalization since no one diet is universal. Okay, getting back to this plate. So here we have this plate. I'm going to have you imagine that's divided in half. Now what half of that plate at each meal to be some kind of produce, fruits, vegetables, etc. And this is where the personalization gets into it. So what a client's like, dislike. Okay, if they don't love strawberries for example, that's not a great recommendation. So figuring out with them what they can fill up that plate with. And now let's be honest, that might be way off the charts for them. Most people eat about two or so servings of total fruits and vegetables a day. Now I'm saying half a plate with produce, that might be a pretty big leap for them. So figuring out where they are, meeting them where they are and starting small is important. Okay, so we have half the plate is filled. The other half of the plate now can be divided into two corners. One quarter should be some kind of green. Kind of green, quinoa, brown rice, white rice, oats, depending on what you're making or eating. Pasta, fero, there's tons of options there. The last quarter of the plate should be some kind of protein. Okay, so about what fits in the palm of your hand. The thickness inside of the palm of your hand could be a little bigger than that. It should be protein. And that could be an animal-based protein, chicken turkey fish, pork, meat, whatever. One of those options or others, others out there as well. Or there's other non-animal options. It's eggs, tofu, beans, this combination of these things, beans and rice together. Lots of different options. So again, it doesn't have to be just an animal-based diet, doesn't have to be a vegetarian diet, some combination or even more important than that, talking and working with your client to see what would best fit their needs and their desires. That's particularly important when we start to get into the personalization of this. Right? Again, what fruits and vegetables do they like and do they think they can enjoy on a consistent basis? And I keep saying fruits and vegetables, you know, keep in mind a lot of times people clients train or say that I've heard bananas or hines sugar or mangoes or whatever it may be. I'm here to say that I've been a dietitian about 20 years now and I can assure you I've never talked to someone and be like, you know what? It's the blueberries. If we could just scale back on those, you're skyrocketing success. It doesn't work like that. All produces amazing, enjoy it on the regular. And then again, allow for some flexibility. What greens do they like? Don't they like? Mixing and matching to meet them where they are? Along with providing some quality suggestions, so they can make this work for them. You're out with coworkers, you're out of the social event. Well, how can you generally estimate how a plate may be broken up? There's so many different options. Again, we don't always eat off the plate either, right? So it's personalization. Maybe it's your beta smoothie. So how would you break down that smoothie? Well, you have the protein powder, you made it with milk, put some fruit in there. So figuring out and talking with your clients, the ball, we eat it a ball sometimes. It's a ball of cereal. Well, you have the milk for protein, the cereal for the grain. You put some fruit on top. So we can mix and match to make this work for our clients. Nutrition is in black and white. And again, our job is to help them figure out what can work for them, figuring out their identity and how they can best fuel their bodies. Here's an example of someone I worked with. So I worked with a professional athlete and she traveled a little over 300 days a year. Yes, I said over 300 days a year. When I was talking to her, she had mentioned that she was not going to be home again for the next two months, not in her own home for two more months. That means she was going to be flying in planes all night, many nights across the world on a consistent basis. Thinking about how I talked to her about nutrition, it's going to vary a lot from someone who is a stayed home mom or dad, for example, or even just someone who works in traditional, come in nine to five job. Right? So we need to think about their personalization, working with clients to meet their needs to meet their desires and really then ultimately helping them get to that outcomes they want. So there you have it. We think about how to build a plate as an easy way to think about these tiny habits over time. Making that plate work may not be an overnight switch and having breakfast lunch in dinner, right? But over time, what you want to get to is aiming for that goal for your clients to best serve themselves and get their desired outcomes. We'll see you in the next video.

=== FILE: How to Help Clients with Nutrition Habits [KbC3I8uC3lc].txt ===

Good afternoon everyone and welcome to NAS and live. My name is Prentice. I'm here with Crann Caramore from more results. And today we're going to talk about how COVID-19 has shaped nutrition and exercise habits. Thank you both for joining us today for this webinar. Before we begin, can you tell us just a little bit more about yourselves and your business? Yeah absolutely. That's actually having us great to be here. So our business, our backgrounds are in exercise physiology, both of us are PhDs in exercise physiology. And I'm also a dietitian. And we work a lot with corporations and companies and helping them and individuals kind of hard there there well being challenged, whatever that may be. Helping with nutrition habits, exercise habits as well. Yeah and so my background is in psychology and then all of my work has really been in taking the principles that we know around exercise physiology, around getting people to be more active, to change their nutrition habits. How do you actually apply that so that it becomes sustainable? So it becomes lifelong and that's really been my passion. And so I get all neat depth on how we form new habits and what we do to really support them. So it's fun to be here and to have this conversation today. Well thank you for, thank you again, thank you for joining us. === FILE: It's Not About The Scale [t5dW_1DuRrE].txt ===

Alright, your client walks into meet with you. After the essential niceties are out of the way, they start sharing some of their goals. Priority number one, getting the number on the scale to move in the right direction. And in their words, unsaid does they will finally be happy. Can't queue the records scratching on the turn table. That is not how it works. Well, you want to be supportive and help them work towards their goals. Here's a phrase to keep in mind. Tell them what they want, but give them what they need. You want to speak their language. And if the scale weight is what they're after, then it's not your job to completely discredit their outcome. That said, we encourage you to focus on the process of getting there, rather than the outcome of being there. And also help people turn their focus to other outcomes rather than simply a number that is measuring your relationship with gravity at that point in time. What about their energy? Did the close fit better? Is it easier to move, walk up and down the stairs, get up and down off the ground? At their last checkup, maybe they've learned their blood work hasn't improved. Maybe they're not as out of breath when they're running around with their kids, or the grandkids. All these little bits really make someone feel better. You know, maybe by changing their eating and exercise habits, they found a new sense of confidence and a boost in self-esteem. So many positive outcomes that aren't related to their weight at all. The list is endless. And none of them, again, have to do with a number. None of them. So we're not saying if someone does have a weight loss goal to completely discourage them, but rather along the way, focusing on the other benefits, though are these small wins. They can go a really long way to help build habits. Now, let's take a look at how this habit loop can play out in real life. In the last video, Karatalk talked about the cue, craving response and reward. Mary, let's say Mary, comes to you and has laid out some health goals. Now, as you talk through a typical day with her, she tells you that she struggles with the mid-afternoon slump, like so many of us. She typically works through her lunch, spends the next couple hours on confidence calls or in meetings, and then 3pm hits and she completely tanks. Her energy, her mood, and is taken out on everyone or anything in her way. Okay, let's plan this out using the cue, craving response and reward. Mary might start with a bad emotion. That she doesn't like how she feels in her body. This is her cue, which may have been brought to her, brought her to you in the first place. That cue that makes still craving, which in this case is her internal desire to change because she simply wants to feel better. The desire to change in this case would lead her to you, the trainer, as a response or maybe making some changes with her own nutrition plan. But then the challenge here is what she desires, and that is losing weight, which is outcome driven. Unfortunately, the outcome of weight loss is detached from the immediate choice of the behavior. For example, meeting friends, again, on a Tuesday night for happy hour, isn't connected to the outcome of reaching a specific body weight six months down the road, let's say. So with her ultimate reward being the scale, encouraging her along the way, it could be a challenge. If instead, the discussion is around those small daily wins, educating her through these daily choices could go a really long way. How can she reward herself with working out? Or better for your foods or swapping out choices as process outcomes instead of setting her eyes on the final outcome goal. Again, that term process outcomes is important, not looking at the final number of final goal, but what it takes to get us in the air. More videos on this topic as we continue on.

Something that I feel is very important and I speak about this and on my classes and every single person that comes through my door. They go through an assessment process that first session and it could take an hour and a half whatever it takes it takes. And I want to do their whole medical history. I want to know everything that happened. You spraying drink when you were 14. Great. You know I want everything because what I see with your body and movement today is probably because of all of those things that happened in the past. So I need to know and have the biggest picture possible. Then we do movement and I watch their body mode move and I can see different patterns. I can see where weaknesses are. I can see where and balances are. And then that can speak with their medical condition and we can say okay I have a better picture of you. Now let's do these exercises. Now let's create something that's been bothering me in the last probably three to five years is the big push on mobility. I can't tell you how many people and I think mobility is incredibly important. We need it. However, what I'm seeing is too many people are focusing only on the mobility aspect and now leaving aside stability. And they're having people who are way too hyper mobile. And if you've ever worked with a dancer you're in New York you work with dancers. You work with a hyper mobility issue that's a huge issue. Huge issue. So now we have these athletes coming in who are working on nothing but mobility exercises and they're not stable at all. I've had professional athletes here on my table and I have them do the simplest exercises and they can't do it. Because they have no stability and it's like okay we have to create that. And it may take us a week it may take us a month but once we create it it's great. And then they say I'm so much stronger now. Well good now we've worked from the inside out. Right and isn't that interesting too because I think probably one of the more fascinating things is that you get these really strong athletes on the table and you do your work with them and you focus on stability and you don't focus on strength or power or force output or anything like that and then you run through a stability program and then suddenly they're stronger in every other way. And it's pretty remarkable to see it and to experience that first hand. But when you get somebody that is unstable then you kind of the central nervous system down regulating that information that feed to the other muscles around it. I am not going to allow the deltoids to work as much as they need to to go overhead press if the shoulder is unstable and it's going to turn down and down regulate that activation and in those muscles all around the shoulder and the shoulder girdle. And so all you're doing through stability is giving them access to strength that they already own. They may already have the strength in their shoulders and their triceps to press overhead they just can't access it. So the thing that I've realized over the years I don't know about your age I'm not gonna ask your age I'm 49. The older I get and the more I've seen with clients certain muscles atrophy naturally just through age. Aging disuse certain muscles automatically automatically atrophy and they get weaker. And what I find is a lot of those are the stabilizing muscles. So that we become progressively weaker and weaker and weaker even though we seem to be strong but we're not like you said our center nervous system isn't supporting our system. So we're not strong. We're not maintaining that stability so our joints are working the way they're supposed to. They're not working with proper joint congruities so they're not going to support what we need. When we're young we have all that support and it comes naturally how many athletes in their 20s do we really have to work on stability a lot of them come naturally. We have to do a little bit but it's not the same as a 45 year old athlete where we have to really focus now on a lot more stability in order to get them stronger again. And I get that I get the athlete who's been you know on the industry reserve for a couple of seasons or whatnot and they say I just can't seem to get back to where I was and I say well it's because you're still training like you're 25. You're not 25 anymore. Now we need to train you a little bit differently and focus more on other things and suddenly we're focusing more on longevity and training for life and now they're feeling better they are stable. They are mobile in the right ways and oh my gosh they're about moving properly. === FILE: NASM Built Different Everett Miner [4eBAcwhBQAE].txt ===

My name is Everminer. I'm the owner of Minor Fitness based in Arizona. I do hybrid coaching, which is a combination of in-person and online coaching, tell my clients, stay more accountable and get the best results with a full transformational coaching plan. Going from in-person sessions and you have that hybrid mix and then over time you're able to transition to online coaching to maintain the proper programming and accountability over time has just been tremendous for both my self and clients. Continuous learning has been everything for me and that's why I got my Nazam certification to start. Everybody that's looking for a personal trainer wants someone who certified, they want someone that's knowledgeable and trustworthy and without that certification you are just not going to be reputable in the space. Selling is a lot like trying to sell yourself on a dating app. It's really trying to set yourself up for that first date where you're trying to get someone in for that console, aka the first date and you really don't want to give them many reasons to say no. You want to give them every reason to say yes to come in, see the facility that you're working at, see what it's like to work with you, give them a tailored experience that they're not going to be just another client under roster that you're giving a cookie cutter program to realizing that selling single sessions or packs of sessions just kind of creates unstable income because you have cancellations and you know people go on vacations and no shows and you really need something much more stable to stay in the game as a personal trainer. So subscription based model is going to be the way to go and you know this just comes after going through some ups and downs in the business where I realized things had to change or else I wouldn't be able to make this work in the long term. Do so many reps that it would be unreasonable for you not to be successful and that really resonated with me because I was relentless in my pursuit of starting up this business and I knew I had a lot to learn and you know being a coach versus being a business owner is sometimes too completely different ball games but I knew that if I tried enough avenues that eventually something would pan out and I would learn the information that I needed from the right person hopefully at the right time. I strategically scoped out new apartment complexes in Scottsdale and I came across one that was luxury and had a couple gyms and I could just see myself training people there. I thought it was a business opportunity so I worked with people in the releasing department there to hand out and put up flyers, put stuff in welcome packets and send out email blasts, I ran a free boot camp to get the word out there and get some more lead generation, digging in terms of systems and scalability because you are the trainer, the marketer, the salesperson like you're doing everything and being all things you have to just accept that there's a major learning curve for all these different skills and positions that you're going to have and that's just part of the course it's part of the game and you need to embrace that grind and the struggle to then make it like if you want to be a business owner then it's going to take a disproportion amount of energy time and resource upfront to build what you want in the long term. Coaching people the way that I want to and that I wish I had gotten and I built minor fitness from scratch based on solving the exact problems that I had and it just leaves me very fulfilled to know that I'm helping people with the same issues that I had and I'm just grateful for the opportunity every single day even when I have to get up super early for six AM sessions.

=== FILE: Nutrition and Behavior Change Introduction [ajqHHkfBB6I].txt ===

Hello and welcome to How to Form Nutrition Habits. I'm registered dietitian Dr. Chris Moore and I'm behavior change expert Dr. Karam Moore. Together we work with clients to not only educate them about nutrition but we coach them on how to put practical nutrition strategies into practice until they become lifelong habits. As more of the reviewers and editors of the NASM Nutrition Certification, I knew this video series would be one that we will receive by trainers working so hard to help clients reach their goals. One is that work for them and with them without challenging their identity. Now what we'll explain with that means how do you work with someone to figure out their identity and how does that align with their goals? Too often when we're working with somebody we try to instill our own goals on them. Eat this, don't eat that or do this, don't do that. With just like every single person who will be training isn't immediately rushed over and put under a barbell to do a set of squats, not everyone walks into your gym will have the same outcome goals or strategies to get them there when it comes to nutrition. This video series will help identify some of the important steps within the process of creating habits. How do you build positive ones? How do you teach clients to unlearn the negative ones? The end, what is the power of teaching clients to address their own sense of identity so that they can make small changes that will ultimately add up to big results? We'll pair this information with specific nutrition tips, tools and strategies that we've used with our own clients to help them reach their goals. These short videos were created in order to build upon one another. Almost like habit stacking, a concept will discuss in a future video and also as a way to complement the information that's contained within both the nutrition and behavior change certification programs that NASM offers. Thanks for joining us and we'll see you in the next video.

So, you know, falls among the elderly, especially those with osteoporosis, are associated with high morbidity and mortality and involve high-cost medical intervention. So in fact, falls are responsible for 90% of the growing increase in hip fractures and are the six cause of death among patients over the ages of 65, which is crazy to me. But falls are multifact rural. Their causes are categorized by intrinsic, which just means personal and extrancy, which is an environmental factor. So some examples of intrinsic include altered balance, neurological disease, sensory deterioration, excuse me, musculoskeletal diseases, phosphohypertension, and of course the use of medication. Research shows that altered balance is the greatest collaborator towards falls in the elderly with the high correlation between balance deficits and the incidence of falls. And so for this reason, you know, studies regarding the risk of falling in osteoporosis are at a high priority in clinical intervention, which diminishes the incidence of fall, which is a health priority, which reflect both on the quality of life and health costs long term. === FILE: Opening a Fitness Business Navigating Expenses, Taxes & Family Finances [PJyuK59fSyo].txt ===

On today's episode of NASM, CBT podcast with me, Rick Richie, I explore a question Ellie asked about taking three to five years to pay yourself back after opening a business. What it costs to go as an independent as a personal trainer, which won't take three to five years to pay yourself back, and why it isn't always the best way to go. We also talk about taxes for a few minutes too. I'm just stick with me through that one. I also spend some time talking about what it is like to open a brick and mortar business, which may take three to five years of being open just to pay yourself back for all the costs of opening the business. That is if the business doesn't fail. Yeah, I'm so sorry. You're going to want to listen to this one. Make sure that you like, follow, subscribe, and leave a five star review. Now, here's the episode, how do I pay myself back when opening a business? You're listening to the NASM, CPT podcast with Rick Richie, winner of the shared Care Emiel Ward for social storytelling, and the official podcast of the National Academy of Sports Medicine. Hey, all and welcome to the NASM, CPT podcast. My name is Rick Richie, and I got a message, and I thought it was such a good question. And there's an interesting flaw in the question here, which is there are two things that are conflated that don't need to be. So I'm going to address this. So the question asks, is this? Hi Rick, just call me LA have a question for the podcast. I've recently decided to be an independent trainer, congratulations. In preparation, listen to some of your episodes regarding what it really takes financially to be independent. Your episode about making sure you account for taxes, retirement, business expenses, etc. Brought up another question for me. It says a lot of entrepreneurs will tell you that it practically all of your profits that you make in the first three to five years of opening should be poured back into your business. That's the case. How exactly am I supposed to determine how much I get paid? How do I pay myself, man? I don't mean no. Do I have to support myself and my family? I mean, I do have to support myself and my family, right? Does it? My family scrape by because I'm investing in my business or is it appropriate for me to pay myself? Well, at the expense of building a business. What are your thoughts? Thanks for everything. Well, I have some opinions for you. I have some non-appinions. I have some just the state of facts here. And so we've got to talk about it. But I will start by saying this. My wife always asks me, when do we get to keep the money? So I have now six gyms in New York City and we have a smaller apartment than we want to have. So we have a lot of apartments, cost of fortune in New York City. So do building out gyms and had we built spent less time building out gyms? We probably could have spent more time in focus getting a larger apartment for our family here in New York. Well, there's a problem. We can go up and we're in a small apartment. If we can increase the size of our apartment, it increases what we need. Not even what we want is another couple of bedrooms and at least one more bathroom. But that cost another million dollars in New York City. So what does that mean? That means that putting money back into the business because even if we kept all the money from one gym or two gyms or three gyms or four gyms, it would be very hard to save up to buy a larger apartment. So what do we do? We actually put the money back into the business and take a few years as you talked about to start paying ourselves back. But then we have an income from multiple different sources. But there are two concepts that are conflated here and they're put into one. So first, let's discuss going independent as a trainer. You are spot on regarding putting aside money for tax. It's here's a breakdown of how tax liability for an individual works. We're going to go all the way up to $100,000. I'm recording this in 2025. So as it stands assuming you're filing as a single and you're not. You have a family but we're just going to go this as a single and it works out better for you to get some family because you got some right-offs. But here's the thing. If you make up to $1,9,000, your first $11,925, that's taxed at 10%. As we go into this kind of progressive taxing system, the next $11,925,248,000 plus change is 12%. Now the first $11,000, almost $12,000 is 10%. The only 12% is basically that $12,000 through the $48,000. Then you've got kind of the almost $49,000 to $103,000 is taxed at 22%. Then you've got the tax bracket of $133,000 to $150,000. That's 24%. Now the total tax liability is you've got to add all of that up. And so if you added up, then that's going to be what's called your effective tax rate. So your first 10%, your first $11,000 plus dollars is 10% and then the next 12,048 is taxed at 12% and the next is taxed at. So it's not like people say I don't want to make $500,000 because I go into the next tax bracket and now I've got to pay way more in taxes because you don't pay, you just pay anything above $500,000 in the next tax bracket. You don't pay everything you made below $500,000 at that tax. So there is a challenge here. So the key takes away, take away is here. You're not taxed at the highest bracket rate on your entire income. The only income that falls within the bracket is subject to that bracket specific tax. Right now as a business owner, you will be responsible for this money. But you're going to also have to put money aside because that's just your federal tax. You've got to put money aside for your state tax. Now that's why people love states like Florida because they don't have any state income tax. But it was supposed to be, I believe they were going to track this over six weeks and see what kind of changes remain. And it turned out that nobody made it to six weeks because their feet started hurting to bad from all the standing and walking. So the point of that story there is whenever we, whenever we see things like hourly movement, we have to keep in mind that if we're taking a population that's been sitting, you know, on their, on their rear working for, you know, in some cases 20, 30 years basically, we want to make sure we're not throwing them into something to where they're standing at their desk for hours per day. And they're walking and they're doing these things. So we're not really throwing them to the other end of that spectrum of moving so much that they start to get painful feet. So we have those two branches of the nervous system. sympathetic always trying to respond to stress, get everything ready to respond to, you know, dense stressors. And then we have our parasympathetic rest digest in recover. These are constantly playing a game of tug of war, literally at every single heartbeat. Over time our body is going to make adaptations as a portion of our lifestyle. We'll see, for example, smokers tend to be more sympathetic dominant because they're always applying this kind of toxic substance into their bodies. They're bodies always having the stress and kind of recover from that. We see other people with things like adrenal fatigue, right? They've stressed so long for so much that now they're hypothernalist, but to a period of adrenal glands just can't keep up and it's decided to stop doing its job. Now they fall so deep into parasympathetic that there gloomy and mope all the time and they just can't produce energy. So it's really about maintaining the proper balance and understanding that that balance is somewhat of a function of your goal where you're sport. Hop on one leg, which is good balance practice, and then we're going to do one more. Gallup. We're going to do a Gallup. Okay, so where do you want to start? Do you want me to call or do you want to call red like green light? So this teaches kids about how to start, stop, pay attention, listen to directions as best as you can. Are you going to be the caller? Yeah! Okay, you got to stay still and you got to tell me what to do. Am I going to run? Skip. Hop or Gallup. Red. Okay, so I got to get back. Red. Red. Red. Red. Red. Yellow. Yellow light means do what? Yellow. Yellow. Yellow. Yellow. Yellow. Yellow. Yellow. Are you going to meet a caller now? Yeah! Okay, so I want you to Gallup. So Gallup means taking one foot in front of the other. Green light. Gallup. Gallup. Gallup. I'm going to get you. I'm going to get you. What move is next? Skipping or hopping? Skipping. Who's going? Me or you? Green light. Green light. Green light. Green light. Green light. Great. I just tried to have fun with your kids. Teach them how to start and stop. You can even pick for older kids. All right. So, first, let's talk about some common injuries to the the foot ankle complex and or the the lower leg. Uh, basically, we're talking about, you know, from the knee down. And, you know, Ken mentioned this, but, you know, the most common lower extremity injury in the athletic population is going to be an ankle sprain. And I guess, you know, because we have a wide array of professionals that are probably listening, just want to make sure that everyone's aware of the difference between a sprain and a strain. A sprain is going to refer to an injury or an overload to a ligament, whereas a strain is going to focus on muscle tissue or injuries to a muscular tenderness tissue. Ligaments relatively in elastic tissues, um, their primary job is to provide support and stability to the joints. They also control the position of the bones during joint movement. And they provide, a hydrograph appropriate sub to the point, uh, excuse me, appropriate sub to input or joint position sense to the central nervous system. So, ligaments, uh, origin receptors, and they provide information related to the position of the joint, and then the body can react and respond appropriately based on that feedback. Um, the most common ankle sprain is going to be what we refer to as a lateral ankle sprain. So, that's going to be, uh, you know, an injury to the lateral ligaments of the ankle, um, you know, most common injury by far and in, uh, and most prevalent in field and court, uh, base sports, uh, the, uh, the lateral ligament that's, that's often most injured is the ATFL or anterior tibial fibular ligament. Um, it's the weakest of the, the ligaments, lateral ligaments, and therefore it's, it's injured with the greatest prevalence. Um, some other things you have to consider with a lateral ankle sprain are, you know, bruising, potential bruising to the tailus, which may prolong some of the recovery time associated with an ankle sprain. Um, and then I think, as a release to what we're talking about in reconditioning and returning an athlete or a client to full performance is the longer term effects of, sorry, guys, my screen, uh, my screensaver came on, um, threw me off. The, one of the biggest things that we have to consider when it, when it comes to the, the long term effects of an ankle sprain is what we refer to as chronic ankle instability. So you'll often see the acronym C-A-I, um, chronic ankle instability occurs in, anywhere from 25 to 50% of the population when you look at general population as well as specific athletes, uh, for example, dancers if they spray in their ankles, a higher percentage of dancers who suffer ankle sprains or going to suffer from chronic ankle instability. That's something upper end about 50% and then general population might be, uh, closer to, you know, uh, 40% and then certain other athletes may be on the lower end of the spectrum around the 25%. So that's something that, uh, that you have to think about when you're developing a program to, to get a client or athlete fully backed and reconditioned, is that chronic ankle instability, uh, which will increase the susceptibility of, uh, repeat a recurrent ankle sprain. Um, let's see, the, um, medial, um, medial, uh, lateral ankle sprains, excuse me, is often referred to as an inversion sprain and then, you know, less common ankle sprain is going to be your medial, uh, medial ankle sprain, which is often referred to as an eversion sprain. Um, and then the final thing that you might hear about or final type that you might hear about is, is a high ankle sprain, which is also referred to as a syndismotic sprain. And really, that's an injury to the interacius ligaments between the tibia and the fibula. Um, usually it requires a longer recovery time and, um, you know, therefore may require a little longer, uh, immobilization and, um, your athlete or client may have, uh, greater difficulty with weight bearing or returning to weight bearing with a high ankle sprain. Um, but regardless of the type of sprain over time, as you start to recondition the client or the athlete, the approach that you would use is going to be very similar. Um, and that's, uh, that's a, that's a good thing. And, you know, neuromuscular efficiency that turns thrown around a lot in the NASM materials, but that's essentially just ensuring that all the right muscles are, are working together to be able to to control dynamically control e-centric forces on the body in all planes of motion, stabilizing against those, which then provides a solid platform to be able to produce force concentrically and accelerate forces. So, is everything working as it should, are they able to maintain proper alignment or all the right muscles firing in the right sequence with the right amount of force in order to accomplish the task without compensation. You know, you know, can they control their body? Or how hard they're going to hit me? But, you know, what I can control is, okay, what can I do to train my ability to hold my place in space? So, there's, there's the ability to produce as well as reduce force and I think when it comes to return to performance, it's the ability to stop whether it's to stop your body or to stop somebody else's body and hold your place in space. So, that's the number one thing when it comes to coordination that I think a lot of us never learn or if we've learned that we don't apply it. And those are going to be really, really important and beneficial to a lot of these conditions or injuries that that you might encounter, particularly the foot and ankle, but also as we get into other parts of the body. So, you know, eccentric, focusing on eccentric stimulus to the tissues, the ability to asymmetrically stabilize in different positions and at different tissue lengths is going to, is going to be really beneficial and has been shown to be very impactful when it comes to coming back from some of these things. We have to talk about the actual strategies and programming. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. So when it comes to, when it comes to the actual programming in this sense, you know, we are going to leverage the NSM corrective exercise continuum for our framework, where, you know, for those of you who aren't entirely familiar or maybe not familiar at all, the corrective exercise continuum is a force that process the consists of, you know, the first that being inhibit and we're going to utilize different techniques and tools to relax or decrease overactivity in certain tissues that and, and muscles that may contribute to a faulty movement pattern. The second step is what we call lengthen, where you're going to incorporate stretching techniques or flexibility techniques that enhance the extensibility of the target muscles. So the goal with these first two steps is to restore or, and or enhance available range of motion. And that's going to set you up for greater success in the next two steps, which are activation. So once you've improved or enhanced the ability for the joint to move through range of motion, then you want to re-train or develop greater muscular control through that range of motion. So activation is going to be done on muscles that have been identified as as being relatively underactive that might be allowing a particular faulty movement to take place. So you're going to do specific exercises and techniques to re-engage those tissues. And you're going to work those through that new range of motion that you've attained from the the previous two steps with the flexibility techniques. So inhibit lengthen and activate or, you know, strengthen if you will, inhibit lengthen, strengthen. And then the final step is what we call integration where, you know, you've restored range of motion locally to select joints. You've developed isolated strength around those joints and control through those specific ranges of motion. Now we want to integrate that into more functional pattern, more functional body position where the joints that you just impacted locally have to work in coordination with the joints above and below it and in a variety of different environments. And so that integration step is extremely important. And then with maybe as a a subsidiary or kind of another component to the integration step is, you know, making sure that whatever you do from an integration standpoint is progressive and kind of replicates from a performance perspective what they have to do on the court or in the the sport that they're trying to return to. So that may be specific drills where you're challenging speed, agility, quickness and and other attributes to get the body to respond and perform in an environment that's specific to that person's activity. Did I explain that okay, Ken? You explained it more than okay. And this is the thing about the, you know, when you're working with somebody from a, from a, I guess, a reintegration into sport standpoint is that it's, you know, first of all, you know, you got to get them out of the mindset of sport specific training where you get a human specific training. So we have to look at human movement science and, you know, this is what, you know, it helps facilitate better movement and not just at the side of injury in this case is the footnacle but also how the whole body, you know, how we retich the body, how to use this new updated upgraded, you know, area, which is, you know, again, we go from a position of compromise to to enhance movement. So even, you know, and you've seen it, Tony, you get four degrees better ankle door seat flexion on somebody. Sometimes that's, I mean, that's enough to make. Man, that feels awesome, right? That's, that's the importance of having all four steps put together because it's not just about flexibility, flexibility and of itself is, is nothing. So, something to be aware of there, the other thing is looking at symmetry. So, asymmetries in the body are, again, are another big risk factor potentially for non-contact, Muscle's skeletal pain and injury. And we'll talk a little bit more about this with some of the different tests that you're clients or athletes might go through, but generally speaking, if there's a greater than 10% difference between the injured side and the unenvolved side, then, you know, that's something that, that's a gap that you want to, you want to close down as, as quickly and as much as you can, as, as you get over that greater than 10% difference than the, the risk of of injury is going to, going to go up. But multi-component preventive training programs that include feedback, regarding technique, and, and at least three of the following categories, strength, plan metrics, agility, balance, and flexibility are recommended to reduce non-contact and indirect contact ACL injuries during physical activity. And should be performed at least two to three times per week, not only throughout the season, but also throughout the preseason, as well. We know that multi-component training programs, they're advocated to improve lower extremity mechanics, muscle activation, balance, strength, power, and functional performance measures, as well as decrease landing impact forces. Something that we've talked about, we talked about previously, and we'll talk about again, coming up when we get into the specific programming, is that exercise issue be performed for aggressive intensity levels, better challenging, but allow for excellent movement quality and technique. And, you know, the one thing for personal trainers out there, don't be surprised, and this is where things get cut short when it comes to the rehab process, is that you'll have clients and athletes that feel better just by getting range of motion. So, if you know, sometimes the mentality is in the conversation, I have to have with, with just clients in general, is that, you know, you've got this range of motion, and you've decreased the stress at a given area, and that's awesome. However, now you have all this, what we call, or it can consider naive range of motion. You have all that range of motion, but your brain and your body doesn't know how to coordinate it, doesn't know how to control it, and, you know, from a muscular control standpoint, if you're not confident, if the brain or how you strategize, you know, movement, if there's lack of confidence in you getting so much range of motion, it's just going to take it all back. So, this is where now getting into the next step, which is now the strengthening, compartment strengthening component of program design is important because, you know, they sometimes just because they feel better, they think that's all they need. And flexibility is the key, but unless you teach the body how to use that range of motion and control that range of motion, and be strong with that range of motion, you're going to lose it again, because, you know, as I'm sure you've heard millions of times, is that I stretch and I stretch and I stretch, but I'm still tight. So restoring and or maintaining optimal scapula humeral rhythm is going to be really a critical piece to the puzzle as well. And for those of you who aren't familiar, that scapula-humeral rhythm essentially is basically a two-one ratio of humeral movement to scapula rotation. So as the arm goes overhead for every two degrees, at the arm goes overhead, the scapula moves one degree to maintain the congruency of that glente humeral joint. And you can't look at the body as just a shoulder, just a hip, but when you look at the assessment process and, you know, starting off with just a static assessment, as well as moving on to a movement assessment, the static assessment tells you a lot when it comes to why somebody might be experiencing some stress or how we can get them to move better and decrease stress in a certain area. So Tony, walk us through, you know, when you start to assess somebody, how, you know, how do you start to, how do you actually start the process and someone comes to you and says, or you get an athlete that you're working with and they're saying, yeah, my shoulders kind of tender, been kind of tender after practice these last couple weeks, what do you start to look at? Yeah, yeah, I think from an objective assessment perspective, you know, subjectively obviously their activities and the things that they tell you, based on their history, all that should be taken into consideration as well. But we get into our objective assessments or a postural and movement assessments. First thing I'm going to look at with respect to static posture is their thoracic spine position. I want to see, do they present with excessive chyphosis in the thoracic spine? What's the position of their shoulder girdle or are they in more of a rounded shoulder posture? And then also their head carriage is their head stacked over the trunk appropriately or do they present with more of a forward head carriage? So just, you know, very quickly, that'll give me some insight into, you know, some of the things that we may have to contend with from a programming standpoint. If we see excessive chyphosis in the thoracic spine, we see some rounded shoulders and or a forward head. For many of the regions, we've already discussed if the thoracic spine is rounded excessively. Then, as you try to move the arm overhead that's going to limit or influence the ability of the scapula to posteriorly tilt, which is going to affect range of motion going overhead, rounded shoulder posture, that will also affect the position of the scapula. If the client has more of an anteriorly tip, scapular position, then that's going to affect again the ability for that scapula to tilt posteriorly when when you go overhead, along with a number of other movements. And then forward head position, can you already talked about that? And it's influence based on the muscles and the knack, it's influence on the different joints in the shoulder, SC joint, AC joint, and then also the position of the scapula as well. So in that head comes forward, that's going to create increased tension in the muscles in the cervical spine that could also influence the position of the scapula. So, so, bitually, as we talked about before, the static cross-roleicessment can give us insight into some of the habits of our clients. And maybe we can influence some change by getting them to focus on some of those habitual patterns that they might find themselves in. If somebody is sitting at a desk all day, making sure that they're more aware of how they're sitting, maybe ergonomically, if there's a different setup at work that we need to that we need to address all of that's going to feed into that static posture. And then from there, we get into our movement assessments. We'll look primarily at the overhead squat and the compensations that maybe more important as it relates to this region of the body would be, you know, scapular elevation. So, if you see excessive shrugging as the arms go overhead, potentially low back arching. So, if you see low back arch, you may have to do a couple other assessments to determine if that low back arch is coming from the more from the hip complex or if it's being caused or if it's being attributed more to the lat. But either way, when that lumbar spine goes into extension, the pelvis and sorely rotates, that's going to affect the lat. And that in turn is going to affect the shoulder. And then the big one is to the arms fall forward. Do they migrate more into adduction, laterally in the frontal plane or do the elbows flex? And any one of those things indicates that there's, you know, some additional mobility assessments that should be done in the shoulder complex to kind of drill down, you know, what muscles are overactive, what muscles are relatively underactive and and that will help guide your programming. So, yeah, anything else you look for, Ken, in the assessments? With the static, I mean, that's that's pretty much it. I mean, they, I would say, and I don't know if we've brought this up before in that, you know, when when we're doing a static assessment, the last thing we want to do is tell somebody, I'm going to go look at your posture right now because instantly what are they going to do? Or maybe even you look at, you know, when we talked about the hip, we're talking about, you know, looking assessing the iliac crest, and you might notice a, you know, one might be a little bit higher than the other. Of course, that's a reflection of also what's going on with the, with the hip itself, as well as the foot position.
