Now we want to look at how does this, how does this person interacting with the ground and how is their body responding? And the assessment gives you great insight on that. So, you know, but a lot of good stuff, I think when Alan Russell looked at me, I think he saw all three of those arm, so elbow flex, elbow fall to the side, and it fall forward. So I think I showed all of those to different degrees. Now, now, you, you've, again, you've worked with high-level athletes, you've traveled with some athletes. Now, if someone was if a player was a thrower to an extent, how would you address the hips? Because we talk so much about the hips in last week. We talked about the hip complex. How would you address the hips as it relates to the shoulder? Yeah. Well, you know, the, the hip complex we've talked about how integral it is. Based on that regional interdependence model, but, you know, things to look for, again, from a mobility perspective, we'd want to look at things like hip extension. So doing the modified Thomas tests, as an example, if the, the individual, active extension, then they may compensate through the Lumbar spine, which is then going to affect the lat and feed up into the shoulder. But the other big one is going to be hip rotation. And so we know that hip rotation, both on the, on the, the trailing hip, as well as the lead hip, can have profound impact on the shoulder and can lead to increase stress on the shoulder if there's a lack of, of rotation on both on both hips. So, for example, let's say you're dealing with a right-handed thrower, a right-handed pitcher. If they lack, hip internal rotation on their trailing hip, as they go through cocking, the arm back, if they can't internally rotate through that, through that loading phase, then it's going to require them to externally rotate the shoulder to a greater degree. It's going to cause them potentially to arch through the spine to a greater degree, all in an attempted to to gain more eccentric load. In order to produce more force concentrically through through acceleration. So, if you can't internally rotate over that back or trail hip, basically you're going to be stuck in more of an externally rotated position at the hip, which means you're going to have to compensate through the the upper extremity with more external rotation and extension. And as you get up into the shoulder, if there isn't, if you go through more external rotation while in most throwers, you're going to see more external rotation range of motion because of what's required during layback, that can increase anterior instability in the shoulder. So, that can create irritation and lead to pain and issues there. But then you're also going to see more stress to the medial elbow. So, again, if you can't load the hips, you're going to arch through the spine. You're going to have to compensate by trying to externally rotate the shoulder more and that's going to put more valgus stress on the medial elbow. So, when you think about medial elbow stress, medial elbow pain, the prevalence of Tommy John and the increase in Tommy John's that are done. Some of that could be mitigated by looking at hip rotation. We're talking about the trailing hip. Then when you look at the lead hip, as the, as the thrower goes through the acceleration phase and they go to decelerate on that front side, if they lack internal rotation on the lead hip, then they're going to land with that front foot more turned out. And as a result of that, their hip, their lower extremity going up into the, into the trunk, can't decelerate the forces as well. So, when you're looking at dissipating force and decelerating, as they go through acceleration and follow through, if the lower extremity can't offset some of that, then it's going to force the arm and shoulder to decelerate more that force. So, when you look at the posterior rotator cuff and forspinatus, Terry's minor, posterior capsule, that's going to receive more eccentric stress. And then the elbow, as well, is going to receive more eccentric stress, which over time could lead to irritation and ultimately injury. So, hip rotation, when you look at that, there is a correlation between a lack of hip rotation and medial elbow stress and medial elbow injury. So, with overhead and throwing athlete, it's just going to be a key thing. So, again, we're talking a lot about the shoulder complex, but you can't ignore the other aspects of the chain, because throwing is a total body activity. Right. So, and so for everybody listening right now, if you, if you just wanted to get a little snippet of our return to performance for overhead athletes, just rewind the last five minutes. Yeah, so everything too, sorry, Ken, with with the scapcion, again, for those of you who may may not be familiar with the scapcion exercise, basically a scapcion is movement in the scapular plane. And the scapular plane is basically 30 to 45 degrees anterior to the frontal plane of the body. So if the arm was directly out to the side of the body and the frontal plane, you would move the arm forward about 30 to any or from 30 to 45 degrees. And it's in that position where the axis of the humorous is inline with the axis of the scapula. So for a lot of individuals, their movement is going to be much less restricted in this position. If you're going through flexion and abduction in this position, then it might be in purely sagittal plane, purely frontal plane patterns. And so for individuals who have some discomfort in the shoulder complex, the scapular plane is one that could benefit that moving in the scapular plane, activating different muscles in that shoulder complex while position in the scapular plane can be beneficial. Also when you think about return to performance, many of the exercises that we've mentioned at this point are maybe more lower threshold in nature. And so ultimately when you think of the velocities involved and let's say throwing, the forces that are produced and that have to be controlled are are tremendous. And so ultimately when it comes to returning somebody in a full performance, you have to get those muscles, get the, and get the body condition to responding and performing at the speeds and velocities that that they're going to have to contend with during whatever activities are being performed. And so to assist with that dynamic stability at different speeds, you can add in perturbations, which, you know, can we've discussed as a release of the lower extremity and, and hips, but you can also do perturbations for the upper extremity. You can do what's called rhythmic stabilizations where, you know, let's say in an open chain, you could have your client do this with two bang where they just asymmetrically hold their arm and shoulder in a certain position. Let's say it's in a scapular plane. You're holding under the other end of the two bang and you're just applying resistance and various directions that they have to stabilize against. You know, you could do that with a variety of of modalities. You know, talk about going old school, you got the body blade, which provides some of those perturbations and rhythmic stabilization elements there. So you can go through different patterns with the body blade, whether it's a PNF pattern, D1, D2 patterns, flexion extension. You know, this is great where I love to use the hyper, hyper-ish rules, whether it's a Viper or in the case of the shoulder, use the hyper-spear, hyper-spear mini, where you can turn it on and you can adjust the speed, one, two, or three and have your client go through different patterns holding onto the hyper-spear because the vibration stimulates those rhythmic stabilization contractions through the upper extremity. So open chain, you can do a lot of stuff. Any of the exercises that Ken just mentioned, the combo ones, combo twos, cobras, you can do with with the added vibration stimulus and that can add another element to the exercises and the response that you get from the muscles and the tissues. And then you can do those things close chain as well. So again, from integration standpoint, we have our slider variations. You can do perturbations or rhythmic stabilization from a variety of different positions. So if you think of going back to that quadruped position, you can have your client hand on the floor, hand on a medicine ball, hand on hands on a stability ball. All of those, you can perform rhythmic stabilization, whether it's you applying different perturbations to them or you're using various resistance modalities to do that or you're having them perform different movements, which in and of itself provides the perturbation or rhythmic stability stimulus. You've got bear call variations which are fantastic to get those muscles in the scapegoat in the shoulder complex. These mean shoulder complex coordinated and working with each other. Like how much leeway? I mean, there's the textbook, you know, parallel lines between trunk and spine, spine and shin, and, you know, things like that. So how, how do you look at the body or appreciate the differences that each and every client offers and, and how do you address that in your, in your assessment process? Yeah, so I think, you know, one, we've talked about this as a group as well, just understanding the difference between an assessment and, you know, how you might program a squat as an exercise. They may be the same, they might be, they might be different. When it comes to the squat, let's say, from an assessment perspective, we need to standardize the process, so we're always going to have the same set up feet oriented straight ahead and parallel to each other, roughly, you know, hip to shoulder with the part, and by standardizing that set up that allows us to be more objective and reliable in our observations, and it allows us to, to better track progress and changes over time. When it comes to set up for squatting as an exercise, I tend to start off the same way. My goal would be to try to get somebody to be able to perform a squat with ideal ankle knee, hip, and trunk orientations with the feet pointed straight ahead, and anywhere from hip to shoulder with the part. Now, I start there, obviously, there are certain animal considerations that that that you may hear of like hip anti-version, hip retroversion, which is a change in the angle of torsion of the, of the femoral head and neck. You know, anti-version is basically going to be when the femoral head and neck is oriented more anteriorly, which will basically place the hip into a position of greater internal rotation. You might notice a little bit less stability at the hip joint, and a more toe-dend gate with somebody who has, you know, true anti-version at the hip, and then retroversion will be the opposite of that. The angle of torsion is oriented more posteriorly. They're going to be biased, more tors external rotation at the hip. It is a more stable position at the hip, and then, you know, that individual may feel more comfortable and a more toe-doubt type gate pattern. And so when you look at the percentage of the population that has true anti-version or retroversion, it's relatively small, and, you know, there are specific tests that you can, they can be performed in order to determine the level of anti-version or retroversion, but within the scope of the fitness professional or or strengthening conditioning coach, that's not really within, within our scope to do those tests. And so for me, I was just a pro-chit that I'm dealing based on my other assessments. I'm likely dealing with more of a muscular imbalance, and an alignment issue due to either muscle tightness or muscle weakness. And I'll address my programming and address my clients exercise physician based on that. And over time, if I'm implementing what I feel is a correct programming, based on what I see, and I'm not seeing changes, or if trying to get my client into certain positions, creates more pain and discomfort for them, then that may indicate that there's some underlying anatomical considerations that we have to look into, and that may necessitate us modifying our programming because of that. So I think the goal for me would be to try to get somebody to move well from a more neutral orientation. Feet straight ahead, hip to shoulder with the part, and once they've demonstrated good control and the ability to to move that way, and throughout multiple planes, they've achieved ideal range of motion at the key joints involved, then that to me provides the freedom to be able to have more variability in the programming. So if at that point, I want the person to squat with their feet externally rotated and take more of an abducted position at the hip, then fantastic, or if you want to do things with a more internally rotated position, narrower stance, it just allows you a lot more the option for a lot more variability. If you know your client has that optimal range of motion in all planes of motion. So until then, I want to try and get somebody to function well within that neutral range, because if I don't, if I allow them to move in the positions with which they're comfortable, I'm likely just going to reinforce some of the imbalances that I've identified and observed with their movement and with their mobility assessments. So for example, if a client lacks hip internal rotation and as a tournament by my mobility test and during the overhead squat, I noticed that they assume more of an externally rotated foot alignment. Maybe they have to go wider, abduct an externally rotated the hip due to that limitation and hip internal rotation. If I just allow them to continue to squat that way, it's just going to perpetuate the it's going to perpetuate tightness and the muscle and overactivity and the muscles that are forcing them to squat that way in the first place. And so over time, I want to try to gradually reverse posture, reverse pattern, if we will, what they're comfortable doing. I don't notice changes, or there's an increase in pain or discomfort and things aren't improving, then I may have to refer out to a qualified practitioner to be able to do some of those more clinical and advanced tests or imaging to determine if there's other things going on that that are outside my scope. Now, as interesting is as you'd expect, let's say the quarter squat group got better at quarter squatting, the full squat group got better at full squatting. Their performance increased accordingly, but the quarter squat group had better improvements in their, in their sprint time and vertical jump performance. And so when you look at transferance of training and the specific positions that are required for the athlete to perform on the, on the field, on the court. And so forth, just doing a full squat for the sake of doing a full squat doesn't necessarily translate to improve performance outcomes. So, if you're assessing, let's say an anterior pelvic tilt or if you're trying to determine if a client is in more of an anterior tilt then might be considered ideal. Have them go through some active anterior posterior tilt and so as you ask them to perform an anterior tilt, try to assess or observe how much motion they're actually going through and then have them perform a posterior tilt and see how much movement emotion they're going through and if they have more relative motion going into a posterior tilt then that would indicate that they're probably resting or their static posture is in more of an anteriorly rotated position. And vice versa, if somebody has more mobility or is able to move a greater amount when they tilt forward anteriorly then they might be resting and more of a posteriorly tilted position. So, those are just some really simple assessments you can do. So, you know, just to kind of take on, let's say, as a pseudo case study, you know, looking at something like a pure formus syndrome, or somebody is expressing, you know, symptoms or has been diagnosed with sciatic issues, sciatica. Um, just to give us a working template on how we might get somebody to move better with a typical compensation that might come along with it. Tony, where would you start if, if that was the scenario you'd posed with? Yeah, well, you know, I think first just, so we're all looking at the same sheet of music or coming at it from the same sheet of music, you know, a pure formus syndrome, generally is, is a condition or scenario where, you know, the pure, formus muscle is overloaded in some way, and that overload creates some type of inflammation that's, that's having an influence on, on the sciatic nerve in, in that region. And so, that may, that may present itself as, you know, some deep pain in the gluten region. You may get some, some symptoms down the back of the, the legs, sciatic, like symptoms. And so, I guess what we have to do is we have to understand, okay, why is the pure formus getting overloaded? And so, typically what we see is, you know, the pure formus is a relatively small muscle when you compare it to the, the glutes, but often when you see clients who present with, let's say a lack of hip internal rotation during their functional, during their mobility tests, maybe during their movement, functional movements, squat, single leg squat, you're going to see increased adduction and internal rotation of their femur. That may be indicative of decreased glute activation, glute, glute, glute max and glute media. So, the glute max, as you mentioned before, you know, during functional movements, the glute max, its primary job is to decelerate hip flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. Glute media is going to post your fibers in particular, going to decelerate adduction, internal rotation, and flexion. And so, if, if those guys are relatively underactive due to a variety of different reasons or potential causative factors, that pure formus is going to have to load chair and take on the brunt of the work as a result of synergistic dominance. And so, you know, the relative size of that muscle compared to the glutes is small and it's not going to be able to handle that amount of stress. And so, that's going to lead to that's going to lead to that information on that particular structure. And that's going to cause the pain and could potentially create pressure on the side, ignore. You know, we can't ignore the influence of that potentially on the the adductor magnets and biceps for more us as well, where, you know, synergistically those muscles are going to become more active if the glute media's and glute max are not keeping up with with what they need to. So then, you know, with that, you know, more traditional approach for, you know, somebody with that deep, glute and posterior thigh pain would be, you know, let's stretch the heck out of the piriformis. But, basically what we just described, that piriformis is already e-centricly overloaded. So it's already getting lengthens repetitively under load. And so stretching it may offer some temporary relief, but it's just essentially reinforcing the stress that's already being placed on it during movement. And so, I think that from a programming standpoint, what we would want to do is inhibit the piriformis so we can perform a mild, facial, mild, facial technique like rolling or use percussion and vibration over that muscle that will help to kind of down-regulate that muscle decrease its overactivity without without trying to increase its extent to the ability. So, perform an inhibitory technique on the piriformis and then from a lengthening standpoint, lengthen the muscles that could be contributing to that stress, that increase stress on the piriformis. Perform a stretch on the rectus femoris, right? So if this is a client who has an increased anterior tilt and an excessive low back arch, and we want to, we want to address the hit flex or complex. So look at the rect fem. Also, perform maybe a lengthening technique on the biceps femoris, add up to the magnet, maybe the anterior add up to the anterior if there is an anterior pelvic tilt. So, inhibit the piriformis, lengthen the rect fem, biceps femoris add up to the magnet. And then from there we can get into our strength and activate exercises for the glute backslute radius. And, you know, there's a host of fantastic techniques that we can use for that. And basically, just select the best one based on your client's ability to perform the movements without compensation. We also can't ignore the anterior core. So again, if you're dealing with a client who has an anterior pelvic tilt, we want to perform exercises that are more anti-extension focused that can help bring the pelvis back into more of a posteriorly oriented position or closer to neutral. So, you know, things like dead bugs, quadruped opposite arm leg raise, maybe even some crunch variations, planks if you want to get more advanced. And then, you know, sideplanks if you want to look at more of an integrated exercise for the glute medius. And then from an integration standpoint, we want to, to try and get them moving well in all planes of motion utilizing multiple drivers. So, you know, following the purpose-eptive continuum that we laid out a couple webinars ago using a variety of different resistance modalities, different body positions and speeds. So, you know, starting off with, let's say, a two leg pattern like a ball wall squat, for example, where, you know, you can load the hips with minimal dependence on, you know, foot-naked mobility. You can maintain and encourage more of an upright trunk and spine position, which will decrease stress to that particular formus region. And then you can progress to maybe more of an alternate type exercise, whether that's a step up in line lunge in different planes. And then, you know, from there, you can get into your single leg exercises, where now that hip has to really, those glutes really have to work to control the hip and the lower extremity on a single leg. You can also incorporate two blocking, both side to side front to back diagonal. Again, just getting the entire hip complex to work in multiple planes, wall maintaining good core alignment. So, making sure to prevent falling into that anterior pelvic tilt, where, again, we're putting that piriformis in a position to have to take over for the glute complex. And then from there, we can get into, you know, some of our performance oriented drills. And, you know, that can be jump squat progressions. You know, what are some other things? You know, where you might use the upper body as a driver to create stress through the hip, like single leg balance with maybe shoulder swings, or before that, you can even do maybe single leg windmill, where now you're moving the upper body through space to create more stress and perturbation through the hip. I was really struggling with binge eating and I had this mentality related to food that some foods were good, some foods were bad. So it was really destructive and I just found myself cycling between under eating and then overeating. So I became so passionate about flexible dieting because I figured out that you can eat foods that are off-limit and moderation and just decimated this idea of good and bad foods. So at that point I put in my job and I ended up trying to start this company that was based on flexible dieting because I wanted to bring that to the masses and really help people eliminate food guilt and yet be able to maintain their body in a sustainable way. So that's how avatar was founded. And avatar nutrition is it's a digital diet coach. So what it does is it sets your intake of protein carbs and fats. Basically tells you how much you need to eat based on all the anthropometrics that collects about your body and your goal, things like that. And then the real magic happens when it changes those recommendations every week. So there are a lot of apps out there, right? Like my fitness pal, that gives you a starting point of what to eat for your goal. But it doesn't continue to make adjustments as you lose weight. And metabolism isn't stagnant. So that's the real magic behind our system is that every week you weigh in and just like you would with like a personal coach, we look at your progress based on what we predicted and then we change our food recommendations. So that's how avatar worked. All right. So talk to me about flexible dieting and the good and bad foods and I hear it all the time, not just specific foods, but sometimes specific macronutrients, right, that these are bad and I think no one really believes that a macronutrient is bad within itself. But certain foods are always going to be labeled by large groups of people as bad foods. And you can pick about any baked good that you could get in the morning as a breakfast food. And people will look at it and go, oh, that is bad. A croissant is bad. I don't know it is bad. A bear crawlers. And if you think about it, we see them as being bad foods and yet we all kind of want them to some degree or another is flexible dieting just saying at every once in a while give yourself a break. Yeah, I think it is. A lot of people, you know, there's this idea that IF, I am or flexible dieting is trying to fit as much quote unquote bad food into your diet as possible, meaning food that is laden with sugar that doesn't have a lot of vitamins and minerals and it not a lot of fiber, just things that taste good your treats. And that's just not the case. What flexible it does is it allows you to have those foods in moderation as long as it fits in within the entire day and the context of what you're trying to do. So as long as you're getting the right amount of protein that you can have pounds like that as long as you're balancing it out for the rest of the day. So it really does eliminate guilt. And I think that's where this diet is really powerful. So answer it for all of us and answer it for yourself so that we know what you're doing to. Okay, so well first of all, this is fun. Let me take your first question about starvation mode. Let's talk about the principles of weight loss. To lose weight, you need to be eating fewer calories than your burning. That's just how it goes. It all comes down to that calorie balance. Now there's this belief out there like what starvation mode that you can limit calories so much that eventually your metabolism will slow down to the point where it can drop infinitely to prevent you from losing more weight. That just doesn't happen. You see that if you're watching the news and you're looking at some of the war torn countries in the past and places where there was famine, people end up being skin and bones. You know, ultimately you do die from starvation. And if there was such a mechanism that would prevent metabolism from dropping so much that would happen, then you wouldn't see that. That's not to say that metabolic adaptation does not occur because it certainly does. So you would expect just based on losing total body weight and maybe losing some fat remas some muscle. You would expect metabolism to drop a little bit, right? So it takes less energy to move around if you're a lighter person. You would expect that. But with metabolic adaptation, you see drops in resting energy expenditure that far exceed what would be predicted just based on loss and weight and lean mass alone. So that is a thing. But it's limited and how much that can occur. Right? I mean, in some studies you show a 6% drop in the total amount of calories you burn per day. 6%. I mean, that's certainly a drop. It certainly can affect things that might amount to 150 calories. And it could have just depending on how much weight you lose, it could even maybe go as high as like 10%. But it's never going to drop so low that it's going to prevent weight loss. Like eventually if you're dropping calories down, you will hit a point where you're going to start losing weight. It may not be comfortable. You may be really hungry, but eventually you will hit that point. So what happens with these folks who claim that they lose weight eating more calories like and I've had clients have this happen to them as well and people on avatar, you know, where maybe they drop calories down to like what they think is 1,400. And they're tracking that food, they think they're hitting it and they're just not losing weight. And then so I'm like, you know what, why don't we bring your calories up to 1,700? Let's just add 300 calories and see what happens. And low and behold, these folks start losing weight. And they think, oh my gosh, that's magic. I just wasn't eating enough. But what's really happened is mainly two things. One is that metabolism probably has increased somewhat. So when you give people more calories, they have more energy, right? So that means that they're going to probably put more into their workouts. They're probably going to be burning more calories during their workouts. If you have the energy to really go hard, you see it there. You see more calorie expenditure doing basic things like taking walks at night. Maybe they were so lethargic before they were leaning on things. So increases and non-activity energy expenditure goes up, right? So meat goes up. And that's the main reason where people start burning more calories. And it's not a conscious thing. They don't realize it. They're just tired all the time. And when you give them just a little bit more in terms to eat, suddenly they start burning a lot more calories, which in effect puts them back into a calorie deficit and then they start losing weight. So there is a sweet spot for these folks where maybe if you cut too low, you become so left-bargic and your workouts are so horrible that you're just not burning as many calories. Also it becomes really, really hard to stick to those calories. And adherence is another huge problem with these folks. So maybe during the week they're eating, you know, 1300 calories, 1400 calories, 60 days a week. But one of the days a week, they fudge it and they go quite a bit higher. Now they don't necessarily remember that, though. They have this figure, 1400 calories in their mind. I was doing it almost all the time. I've been so good and they had really been pretty good. So adherence, so there's probably combination of the two there. They have better adherence on higher calories. So they're actually probably eating less when you average things out. And also their energy expenditure can go through the roof with meat and just what you're burning in the gym. You know, but this whole finding flexible dieting and the idea that there are no good and bad foods, I mean, it was completely liberating and groundbreaking for me because I was finally able to find a middle ground, you know, where I could be happy. And now I don't even really have to try very hard at all. And I've been flexible dieting so long that I don't have to strictly count to anything like that. Now, after you have sustained a healthy body weight for long enough, those hormones, everything starts to balance out. And I do a great job of knowing when I'm hungry, knowing when I'm full, I can eye protein and know how much I'm getting. And so really, I just, I let my body do a lot of the talking in recent days. I think that that just said, that comes with experience and it comes with time. That's very important for a lot of people to recognize too. So that's really a huge part of it. You've got the thermica effect of food, which is just how many calories you burn to break down food. So when food goes into your body, there's a process of absorbing and metabolizing it and taking it in pathways where it needs to go, that all costs something. That all takes energy. You're almost going to get all those calories. Right? So there's that thermica effect of food. There's the thing that we talked about, which is neat, that you hear a lot about in the literature, which is just how many calories you burn fidgeting pacing. It's not really planned exercise. It's just all the things you do to sustain activities of living. And that is the most variable component, I think, a energy expenditure. And there's a huge genetic component to that. So there were twins studies back in the early 90s that were they overfed, you know, twins by like 1,000 calories. These different sets of identical twins. So they shared the same genes, right? And what we saw was that they all gained different amounts of weight. They all responded differently to those 1,000 calories. Some barely gained anything at all, even though they were being overfed by 1,000 calories for like 80 days. And some gained a ton. I mean, the difference was an interesting thing was there were differences between the pairs of twins, but within the pairs, they were pretty close. So there's a genetic component with how you're how well you dissipate off calories from overeating. And you know, probably the same goes for how much your metabolism adapts to underreeding as well. So there's a genetic component to that. But what we found is that when your body responds to excess calories by burning off more, it's primarily doing that in the form of need. So these people who didn't gain much weight when being overfed by that many calories responded really well. They started, you know, pacing a lot more fidgety and a lot more, you know, they were just highly active people. And then there are the people who just kind of sit there when they're getting overfed and they don't do much more at all. Those were people who store a lot more fat. So it's just interesting that that's the component of energy expenditure that responds so much to more food. And then finally, there's the cost of exercise and moving around. So those are all the components that make up the energy out. Hey, Greg, do we have any other questions that have come through? Yeah, one last one from Ava. She wants to know how can you find the appropriate balance of macros when running recommends 70% carbs. But in order to lose weight, I can't go over 50% carbs. You can, oh, you can lose weight going over percent carbs. It all comes down to how many calories you're eating. So, I think 70% though of your diet from carbs is quite a lot that doesn't leave much room for protein and fat depending on how many calories you're eating. Right? I mean, if you're eating 2,000 calories and you're at 70% carbs, that's 1,400 calories coming from carbs. So, you only have 600 left for fat, which you're probably going to need maybe 400 of those to meet your essential fatty acids. You want to make sure you eat enough fat. But then that doesn't leave enough for protein really. So, I think 70's a little bit high. Any way, depending on what your calorie expenditure is. Now, if you're eating 4,000 calories, that changes things. That leaves a lot more room for protein and fat. Maybe you can do that. But really, there's no magical ratio when it comes to fat loss. And the way I tell my clients to do it is you really want to figure out first how much protein you need. That's going to be important, right? One of the most important macros, especially for weight loss, because it's so filling. And it's also thermogenic. So, like we were saying, it costs a lot more energy to metabolize it. So, you're getting almost free calories that aren't going to be stored as fat from protein. It just really helps with adherence. And then, of course, there's keeping lean mass on, which is important because if you're losing weight, you want most that weight to be coming from fat, not muscle. So, I always tell them figure out the protein needs first a good general, like I talked about protein all day. But a general rule of thumb is really about 0.8 to 1 gram per pound of body weight of protein. So, 0.8 to 1, somewhere in there. And then, figure out your carbs and fats from the remaining calories that you have left. Right? And since you're a runner, you want to make sure that maybe 70% of what is remaining comes from carbs. That's fine. And then, 30% from fat, but 70% of total calories is seems a little bit extreme. But, yeah, again, when it does come to weight loss, remember it is all about the calories. So, there's no reason that you can't lose weight eating more than 50% of your calories in the form of carbs. Gotcha. All right. I like that. Thank you so much for sharing. It took about two months before I really got it and before those cravings stopped. But I don't even crave chocolate anymore, ever, ever. And in 2014, that was my first experience with flexible dieting was, I allowed myself to have a piece of chocolate every single day training for that show. And that was like a pro show as well. They're in Phoenix at the time. And I ended up eating chocolate every single day as an experiment to myself, several pieces, fitting it within my a lot of calories. And I ended up winning that show. I still won that show. And so, it was this light bulb moment that, man, I've been depriving of myself. And that's only made these cravings worse. And I don't need to do that anymore. And once that became something that could be part of my diet, it wasn't, it didn't have this power over me anymore. So I think that's one thing you can try as changing the outlook on it. And as long as it's not like a giant piece of cake, where it's going to take, you know, up a ton of their calories. And then there's nothing left to make sure you're getting your vitamin of minerals from. I think sort of training people to actually implement one of these off-limits things in a couple days of the week, or even a little bit every day may change how the brain sees that food. Now, understand that there's going to be a period of time where it takes a while to get used to that and you're still going to crave it. It takes, it took like I said, some time for me to actually realize that. So that's one thing people can try is actually implementing that snack as part of an organizer. So then the person feels like they're not cheating and it's not bad. So changing their approach to the food. But then, you know, there's certainly other clients that have something coming up and it since it takes a while to change the outlook on that food. Maybe that's something that they shouldn't really be doing at this very moment until you have time to train them with it. And those people who can't seem to stop eating it once it gets in their house, maybe we need to not buy it and have it. So readily available into their house, I prefer option one though. But there's also option two. And then it substituting something in there that's similar for that, right? Like if you're your kryptonite as ice cream, maybe doing something a little more macro friendly like halo top, or you could do the ice cream and just have a smaller serving size. If that works for the person, but if it doesn't, and they've got to have that high volume thing, doing a substitute that's almost just as good in the meantime. But yeah, I think we need to be, what we need to be thinking about with our clients is doing like a complete overhaul of how they see food. And that's going to change the way the brain responds to it once it's no longer considered a goody that's like off limits. I love it. I think it's valuable. It's also really cool to have somebody speaking from an experience that they've had because a lot of times, you know, we get people that can speak to something and they speak to it from their clients perspective or a patient's perspective. === FILE: Self-Identity and the Power of Tiny Habits [Mh31QGrU6jw].txt ===

Hi, welcome back. Many times when clients come to us for help, they are looking to achieve a goal. I want to be stronger. I want to become a better athlete. I want to be thinner. They come in focused on the outcome they want to attain, and they don't necessarily consider who they would need to become in order to achieve it. This is a big gap, however, because our self identity describes who we are. It describes the way we think of ourselves and whether things fit with our image of me or if they feel more like not me. Now who we are determines the choices we make? Determines what we value, and what we decide to do. For example, if we identify as a person who hates exercise or only eats fast food, then no matter how badly we want the weight loss, it will be really hard to achieve that as an outcome. Because the person who has to make the choice day after day to eat healthier and to move their body isn't likely to choose those behaviors, and ultimately won't reach that that outcome. The challenge we all face is the community that we use to describe ourselves, rest directly in the unconscious or the fast-bring side of things. Meaning that if we don't have a lot of time or mental resources, or we are feeling overwhelmed or stressed, we will end up automating decisions based on who we've always been, and not necessarily choose ones that align with who we want to become. Oh, me? Yeah, I don't run if it's under 40 degrees outside. Me and I'm feeling stressed. I'm going to the pantry to grab the cookies instead of working out. Well, say things to ourselves like, this is too much. This feels too hard. I can't make this happen. Now, one of the best strategies you can use with clients who want to make change is to have them spend some time considering who they are currently, and who they would need to become in order to achieve the goals that they've set out to themselves. This allows them to consider what types of behaviors or responses that they would need to choose in order to reach their goals. Do they need to start eating more fruits and vegetables? Or are they going to have to start getting more sleep in order to feel arrested and have the energy for their workouts? Well, they need to limit how much time they spend watching television to get more movement in, or maybe they need to stop hanging out with some friends as frequently as they do. Then, once they've identified what they need to do, you can strategize with them using the conscious slow part of their brain on how they might make that happen. You know, maybe they can make sure that they always keep a set of workout clothes in their car so that they have the ability to go to the gym after work. Maybe they decide that they're going to have to keep the cookies out of the house and just go outside for periodic treats and set up saying that they won't eat them. The other piece of knowing who your client desires to become and what responses they want to choose is that you can help them move in the smallest possible direction toward that new identity. When we choose tiny habits that move toward who we want to become, while still staying in alignment with who we are currently, then we're much more likely to stick with the change because it doesn't feel so drastically different. So what you're going to do is to pass through your degree of check in and broccoli may not be possible for someone who identifies themselves as a veggie heater or a fried chicken fanatic. Someone who dislikes exercise may not be on board with a program that will require them to do five workouts a week. Maybe that veggie heater can agree to eat one piece of broccoli each day or that person who doesn't necessarily like to work out can agree to two workouts a week. If we know what they think is possible and we help them identify small shifts that they can make that move them toward that direction, we can help move them toward their new identity and ultimately their goals. Small changes don't trigger discomfort, fear, or other feelings of, I can't do this, this is too hard and therefore they end up leading to greater adherence and success. We'll talk more about how to apply this with the Mishrushen recommendations in the next video, but for now, know that it's important to think about who your clients want to become and how they can take small steps to move toward that image by having them pick manageable changes that they can do. And with your support of course it'll be easier to reach the outcome goals they desire. We'll see you in the next video.

But there are some reasons that it might happen because some people do it. It's going to increase proprioception and increases the stability of catching a heavy bar. And I think that's important. So it keeps the bar from translating forward and it allows you to be able to land in a flat foot. So you are less likely to do that little forward lean. So there's a reason for that. That weight that impact weight goes from hitting the ground at 256 pounds to 726 pounds. That's crazy. 116 kg at 30 centimeters or landing at 329 kg if you only absorb for 10 centimeters. So one of the reasons that people hard stop or people land hard when they jump off of something is in order to have a greater impact force, what is called the average impact force. And so that average impact force can be really elevated, but it can also be bad for you in some ways. How? Well, if you don't use your muscles to absorb, so instead of bending at the knees and bending at the hips and using landing on the ball of your foot when you jump off of the platform, if you land straight like a jackhammer hitting into a ground, then that is going to be all impact up your spine. And that doesn't help your muscles very much, but it does do something for your spine and it ain't good. So this is why some of the people do the hard stops and their landings, because they can increase their impact force, they increase the stimulation to their muscles. For weightlifting, I don't mind so much if you do that harder landing, because you're looking to increase the stimulus and don't mind it. However, when it comes to performance, you can train impacts like jump downs and feet stomps and things like that. You can do that, but you also have to train elastically as well. You have to train by absorbing and rebounding force. And when you stomp, you cannot rebound force. So use this as just trial it. Try running up a set of stairs as quickly as possible while stomping each stair you go up. Are you going to be incredibly or at least significantly slow compared to what you would be if you just did an absorption. You didn't hear the lands on the steps and you just bounded up the stairs. And the reason that is is because you have a stretch, shortening cycle. But when you don't stretch, when you hard stop, there's not enough stretch there. There's not enough build of potential energy to turn into kinetic energy. So when you turn that into performance, some people are just Olympic lifters. And they like the stomp, they like the stability again. When you hard stop and you feel the floor and you're holding a heavy weight, that can give you comfort. But when you translate that to performance, I don't, again, I don't mind if you do a hard landing off of a box as long as you also practice a soft landing because you do a hard landing, then try to do a rebound jump after a hard landing. You ain't going anywhere. You're not going very high. But if you absorb and then jump, then you've now taken that stretch, shortening cycle. And now you are following up jump. Your subsequent jump from the landing is going to be much more impressive. I won't tell you another group. A group that I like stomping for, and this isn't even weightlifting related. And then I also will have people stomp one leg at a time. You don't want to hyper extend your knee. All of these wonderful things that are going to allow you. And then you're going to stomp with your knee bit more than it usually is. You're going to stomp with your knee without an excessive bend. === FILE: Summary Application and Practicality [w9pJxkyGbRU].txt ===

Alright, so with the series, we talked about practical strategies to best help your clients. Or, it's all to the curve. What we do know is to keep any long-term success, whether that is run nutrition, exercise, or, well, anything is building slowly over time, progress over perfection. Consider this with your clients and even apply it to your own behaviors. Changing habits can feel really challenging, but with the right amount of awareness and support, we can craft the behaviors to help us achieve the goals and outcomes that we want to achieve and become who we'd like to become. So I, this such a joy to work with NASM. Somebody years ago once told me to plan your career around your lifestyle and not your lifestyle around your career. And I've been lucky enough to do that pretty much my entire career so far. So I am a neuroscientist. I was in school for about 14 years. My PhD did a few fellowships. You know, if you want to talk about my specific area of expertise, it's actually looking at sleep genetics. And then get into this conversation about sleep pretty deep and how it can apply to all of us in our clients as well. Yeah, sure, absolutely. So I like to, there's this term that was coined a few years ago. I think by Tim Ferriss and Ben Greenfield called Biohacking. And I think for years that's more or less what we as military scientists try to do is Biohack physiology. And so in order to do that, you have to fully understand it down from, you know, macroscopically at the level of behavior all the way down to the cell. And so that's something we've done in terms of discovering new factors in the brain or even outside of the brain that regulates sleep. So actually one of my claim to themes in the sleep deal. And it's like one of those discoveries I had years ago that will stick with me for the rest of my career is I actually identified a protein and skeletal muscle that has the ability to regulate how much sleep and organism needs. So for years, we always thought that sleep is like by the brain of the brain and for the brain, but it turns out that there is a the sleep set point actually lies in the skeletal muscle. And so it makes sense why there are such close parallels between how much sleep athletes need versus how much sleep the general population needs. Oh, I wish I could just hijack the screen with a blown my mind and mode to the right now. Yeah, right. Oh, no, I've never heard of such a thing. But, you know, it's things like that that we apply to the military because, you know, at the end of the day, we like to study sleep under conditions asleep deprivation because let's be real myself as a soldier myself. And, you know, athletes too, exactly. You know, to this day, I think caffeine is one of the best performance enhancing drugs if it's done right. So we've actually done studies in the military to show that if you consume too much caffeine, it's not a good thing. So it actually ruins any sort of sensitivity you have to caffeine and then too, it's all about when you take the caffeine as well as the source. Okay, so let's talk about what is too much because I know some people and I'm not naming names. I don't know who they are, but you might have a little too much caffeine. Where and how is that line drawn? So it's not so much your daily total intake. It's a amount, the amount you take at a particular time. So literally, we've done these studies for decades. You know, many different schedules of manipulation of caffeine dosing and we found that the body can't take in more than 200 milligrams at a time. So about 200 milligrams is less caffeine than an energy drink. So you can see where I'm going here with this. One of many reasons why energy drinks are terrible for you and they do nothing but harm your body. So I would say 200 milligrams is about two cups of strong coffee because a cup of strong coffee has about 80 milligrams of caffeine. So those, you know, athletes, personal trainers who are taking free workout, those have over 500 milligrams of caffeine. Oh, my goodness. It is doing, again, nothing but harm to your body because that extra 300 milligrams of caffeine, you're essentially just pissing out for lack of better terms. So yeah, we have found that every four hours for about as long as you need, if you're doing 200 milligrams at a time, you should be good to go. Now, for somebody who just wants to sustain throughout the day, you should stop your caffeine intake around early evening. So about five or six PM. So, as we progress through the stages of sleep throughout the night, the deepest restorative stages of sleep are called deep slow wave activity sleep and then REM sleep, which is the stages sleep we dream. And in order to enter REM sleep fully, you have to have a drop in your core body temperature. So, as you can see, if you're sleeping in a hot or a less optimal room temperature wise, you're actually preventing your body from going into the deepest stages of REM because your core body temperature is not going to effectively drop. === FILE: The Habit Loop [rdSmwQsnMDU].txt ===

Welcome back. Let's consider what the normal process of behavior change looks like. Typically when habits are formed, they are formed over time when we begin to perform a new series of behaviors over and over again. MIT researchers discovered three elements that can be consistently found in any habit that we have. These include a cue, a routine, and a reward. This concept is described in the book The Power of Habit by Charles DuPig. In his book, Atomic Habits, James Clear took this concept and went on to expand it to include one additional element. That's the craving. It's this description of behavior and habit loops that I'd like to use to define how we work to build new habits. If you're interested in better understanding how to shape and change either your own habit, or those of your clients, I highly recommend reading both books. Now, behaviors are shaped over time using the following formula. A cue, there's a craving, a response, and then ultimately a reward. As you see, it's with this normal pattern that behaviors are ultimately created. Let's talk through this a bit more to bring it to life with an example. So when we first start talking about the cue, a cue is really anything that brings about a craving. Cue can include the time of day. It might be a person, a feeling or a mood that you're experiencing. It could be a smell or a sound, or even could be a specific environment. For example, you wake up in the morning and that's your cue and it triggers a cascade of habits that you may not even have to think about. You just automatically do those. Maybe you wake up, go to the bathroom, make a cup of coffee, brush your teeth, get rest, etc. Your cue, it's time of day. Or for most people, it's the alarm clock telling them to wake up because it is a certain time of day. Now, sticking with our time example above and thinking about waking up, the craving, or in other words, the motivation behind why you act, is what actually moves you to act. So you aren't necessarily motivated to brush your teeth in the morning, but you really are motivated by the feeling that having a clean mouth and a fresh breath would give you. And you're not necessarily motivated or craving coffee, but rather the feeling that drinking a cup of coffee provides to you. Cravings differ for every person. For some people, they may crave to feel awake first thing in the morning. For others, they might crave that feeling of attacking the day and really getting a jump start on everything they have to do. And general cravings occur because we want to change our internal state. Then we have the response. Now this is the actual habit that you perform. So you do something, you brush your teeth, you drink the coffee, you know, you go to the bathroom. For example, if we're thinking about what we typically do in the morning. Think about what your normal response is to the cue in the morning of waking up and what craving you're actually feeling. Also consider how many responses are possible. So when we consider that there might be a hundred people, they might have a hundred different responses to hearing their alarm go off. Some people may choose to get up and go to the bathroom. Others may go to the kitchen first to start the coffee before going to the bathroom. And some others may decide that they stay in bed and scroll through social media or text messages. So with a hundred different people, there could be a hundred different responses to the same cue. And what determines it is really based on past experience, our own personal preferences, maybe the environment that we find ourselves in, etc. And then finally we have the reward. On one level, the reward is always that the craving is gone. So we wanted to change our internal state and now we have successfully achieved that. And I find that really interesting that we like to satisfy the disc content that our brain creates. And the one hand, the brain is hardwired to notice rewards though from our behavior. So keep in mind, we're always paying close attention to what other rewards and benefits that the response has created. So if the reward also has other benefits, for example, the coffee that we drank tasted delicious or we can now kiss our spouse because we have fresh breath, then it's much more likely that we'll continue to repeat that choice over and over again, forming a habit loop and eventually a habit. In our next video, Chris will talk about the ways that the habit loop can play out in real life, especially as it relates to ways clients change their behavior. Particularly in pursuit of that misleading holy grail of fitness. That's weight loss. Check it out.

=== FILE: The Importance of Recovery After Workouts [jpTxdWXFXcY].txt ===

Welcome to the NASM, CPT podcast, and our Facebook Live webcast. But I want to give a shout out to my friend now, I didn't like him at first, but my friend now, Ken Miller, Ken, thanks for being on with his man. Oh man, the honor and pleasure is my man. I was actually wondering, okay, it's like, did I do some wrong look to Rick because it's totally interviews and I haven't, my phone hasn't rang yet, but no, this the honor pleasure and distinction is all mine. That's the muscle on one side is contracting to try to get the muscle on the other side to relax. I might go into a kneeling hip flexor stretch and do a posterior pelvic tilt and squeeze my glute. My glute activation is leading to decreased LEO so as activation. That reciprocal inhibition, something on one side and inhibiting the thing on the other side. Usually you can hold from one to two seconds some research focuses on even longer times that you can do as well and just do for 5, 8, 10 repetitions and just tuck hold that position back up. Go right back into it. Tuck, squeeze the glute, hold for one, miss the B2, miss the B. And I know that a lot of times the missippies get thrown out and also this goes for the static stretching as well. We look at 30 seconds and LEO used the one to skip a few method to get to 30. You'll go into a stretch and like I won 2, 3, 4, just say I'm going to say 30. Good. And I know because my clients do it to watch my clients they tend to be awful judges of how long 30 seconds is 30 seconds flies by when it comes to their rest and 30 seconds seems like absolute eternity when it comes to e-moms and when it comes to stretching. So with that being said, you all hit a timer. Get your clients real used to hitting a timer. Most people a lot of people have smart watches, a lot of people, if they don't have smart watches, got watches that show second hands on it and just have them do the full 30 seconds for the static even if you feel like that muscle has relaxed, allow for the full 30 seconds to take place. And then you can move into the active flexibility. Now what I like about active stretching as a flexibility technique is that it focuses on giving strength to your new found range of motion. So let's say I've been doing that hamstring stretch. We talked about static stretching. Well great, but if you don't use it especially, you don't use it actively, then you tend to lose it. So how do you use it actively? Well what I might be doing is a kneeling hamstring stretch where I put a leg out in front of me, my left legs in front of me, I'm on the knee of my right leg and I'm stretching and I'm doing that passively, 30 seconds. Well how do I actively stretch that? Well you can lie back on your back and you can pull your knee towards your chest, hold the hip at a 90 degree angle and then just actively extend your knee as far as you can extend it. That is an active stretch for your hamstring. That's an active stretch for your hamstring. You can do it while standing. You can do a straight leg raise which is active stretch for your hamstrings. Where you can go to a 90 degree bend at the hip and then work on trying to build up to a full extension at your knee. And these are all excellent ways that we can try to build active flexibility. And there are all sorts of active stretching techniques that are listed in your textbook. So if you want to explore what those are, then go back to the book and you can check out more when it comes to active stretching. Now the last thing I'm at list is functional flexibility. Now functional flexibility is just really your ability to be functional in your movement because the range of motion is there. Well that includes mobility. So one great example of functional flexibility, squats. Well do you have the mobility to go into that range of motion? Do you have the flexibility to go into it? So functional flexibility, can I do squats? Can I do lunges? Can I do pushups? Can I do it overhead press? All of these things? Where if you get somebody and it's hard for them straight. I had trained one of my guys today. Very, very tight in his shoulders. A big mobility issue. But some flexibility issues as well. Can't take his arm straight up over his head. So we work on what's going on with the tissues surrounding. Now mobility is more what's going at the joint. Does it roll? Does it spin? Does it glide? And I don't see what's happening with him as a mobility issue. It's really a lot about whether or not he can go through that. Now I'll test it actively. I test it test it passively. They are both equally atrocious. So let's focus on building range of motion, allowing the arm to go overhead by self-minefacial techniques to the lats and to the pecs, to the Terry's major. And then stretching. And then we practice actively trying to get it overhead. That's why we look at this as a continuum, the flexibility continuum. Now there is a type of stretching specifically under functional flexibility. And that is called dynamic stretching. And dynamic stretching are the stretches that you might see a lot of people doing. Let's say before they go for a run, right? They're doing straight leg swings. They're swinging their leg. One leg at a time, swinging it in front of them, doing real dynamic hamstring flexibility. It is active range of motion along with momentum. So we're using momentum to swing an appendage through its range of motion. So the appendicular skeleton. And then we can see that with arms swings. We got arms swings. We go across the body. We go up and down. We see people doing circles. We see people doing straight leg swings. We see them in the frontal plane doing swings across the midline of the body and then out to the side. We're the toes tend to point up. That's all different types of dynamic stretching. And with these types of stretching, we are able to get our body used to more sports like activities. Now does that mean that you can't do static stretching before a sporting activity? I would say if you have any clinically type muscles, you should be doing static stretching leading up to it. But if you're going into a high velocity exercise like sprinting, then I'm always including dynamic stretching with that. A lot of times you'll see the corrective flexibility, static stretching, and SMR-SMT, listed as a corrective version. So if you're working on the corrective strategies with people, then you're going to do the corrective version of flexibility SMR-SMT. So self-minofactual techniques and static stretching. As you go into your strength training, you're going to do the flexibility that includes strength training. That's the active type of stretching because it does two things. If I'm doing let's say that hip flexor stretch, I'm increasing range of motion for my hip flexor, but I'm also getting the glute active ready to go do some squats or some lunges. And then the functional flexibility specifically type of technique we're looking at dynamic stretching where I might be doing leg swings, I might be doing knee hugs, I might be doing butt kicks. All of those are dynamic stretches that are active flexibility using momentum as well. All right y'all, thanks for listening and thanks to our producer Eric Sornson. I'd like to ask if it please like, subscribe, share with your fitness friends and family and leave a five star review. If you want to reach out to me like this guy did three years ago, four years ago, hit me up! You can do so on Instagram, dr.ric-richy or email me, rick.ricy at nasn.org, y'all keep inspiring people to fitness. Thanks for listening. This has been the nasncpt podcast.

After you've done your warm up and stretches and foam rolling and all of that, then do an exercise for your chest, your back, your biceps, your triceps, your legs, you know, whether it's the quads or the hamstrings or even your calves, take minimal rest in between those and then repeat it. And then again, very slow controlled movement patterns. And if you do that anywhere from, you know, four to six weeks, I usually say four weeks, fill out see how you feel, see how you're moving, then progress into something different. Then progress into something different. Just bury it up. So if you're looking at your weekly workout, is it something that's repetitive? It's something that it's different? Is it something that's going to challenge the body and doesn't make sense? And as long as you answer like, all of this is going to be good, then you know you're on a really good path. And I think, you know, the big takeaway that I have isn't that pureization has to be complicated. It doesn't have to take away exercises that you like, but just know that if you like to do the same things every time you go into the gym, you will, your workout will become very stagnant. You're not going to see a lot of changes. So think about those exercises that you love and then think how can you vary it up? And it could be just instead of utilizing dumbbells or utilizing cables. And that if always doing stuff with no weights, maybe you're adding smaller weights, maybe you're doing things like you said your base of support. That's super important. So just change it up, have fun with it, but don't do the same thing over and over again. You're going to start to overtrain if you do power all the time. If you do a hit workout all the time, see yourself, the T, you're going to see yourself start to kind of break down. You don't want that. So if you do a hit workout, maybe the next day is the stabilization workout. You just have to change it up. Yeah, and I think people want to see progress. But I think we need to keep the mindset that progress isn't about doing more. You're not lifting more, doing more sets, more reps, more intensity, whatever the situation is. It is about doing the right amount at the right time. So if you've done some strength stability and then now it's time to progress. And then we can get into, like I said, muscular development, max strength, getting to power. But we also have to keep the door open to that, you know, maybe in that example of that busy parent, when do I have my client? And then there are those days where he's just not feeling it, right? His hip has a little song, shoulder has a little something. And then that's when we do that, stabilization training. So from that standpoint, you know, we just had to need to, you know, keep the idea that when it comes to pure disation, the idea of keeping different levels of intensity for the purpose of achieving different adaptations, meaning you're stable, you're strong, and you're powerful. But sometimes you may have to change things up. And that's as a strength coach, I found myself doing that more often than not when it came to okay. Well, the team had a tough three days. So I'm not going to go with our max strength session today. And we need to take the same approach with ourselves and our clientele as a personal trainer or you as an exercise enthusiast, if you're listening to Randolph-Fet here for your own personal gain and improvement. If you guys are familiar with calculating nutrition and RMR and total daily energy expenditure, we're going to break down the differences of why age doesn't determine your caloric needs, but your lean body mass does. So we're going to get away from those empirical values, focus on lean body mass and direct measures. Let's kick it off by defining what is the cutting-ham equation and how does it stack up compared to more common? I'll say it's more common when we're talking just basic nutrition for general population. Equations like the Michelin St. Geore or Harris Benedict. These are really those age-based equations and lay those out for you in just the moment here, but again, those do not factor in the amount of lean body mass or skeleton muscle. So I'm going to define the cutting-ham equation first. If we look at that, the math behind it is RMR or resting metabolic rate, which is really the foundation when we're calculating your nutritional or caloric intake needs. So it's RMR equals 500 plus 22 times lean body mass in kilograms and that lean body mass just to give you guys a little bit more context there. It's basically everything in your body that's not fat, right? So we're talking skeletal muscle, we're talking bone mass, we're talking water, et cetera. Now if we look at the Michelin St. Geore, we're going to take the female version because there's a difference between the male and the female. Again, we have empirical values that are used in each of those equations. So the female, myflin St. Geore equation would be RMR equals 10 times your weight and kilograms plus 6.25 times your height and centimeters minus 5 times your age minus 161. That is a really long equation and if you look back through the equation, no we're in there just at a count for lean body mass, right? You'd have similar results if you look at the hair spenidic or the male version of cutting-ham. Now when we look at those age-based formulas, the problem with these is they can really tend to under or overestimate the caloric needs and we're going to get into a very specific case example in just a moment here, but just kind of high level if you think about it, the logic behind it is very easy to follow, right? If we've got 120 pound female physique athlete, let's say it's a bikini competitor and we've got two of them. One is 10% body fat at 120 pounds and one is 25% body fat at 120 pounds. So if we use those age-based formulas, if these girls are the same age, it's going to say that their caloric needs are going to be the exact same if they're cutting into a show or maybe they're reversing out and they're trying to build muscle, right? So we need the mat of surplus. As opposed to taking something that factors in that amount of lean body mass, like the cutting hem equation, this is going to make a very big difference in how much we feed this particular athlete based on their muscle mass and the fact that metabolism is functioning in a much higher rate, right? That's that metabolic building phase that we talk about so often in bodybuilding. So with that, I'd love to break down an example comparison. We're going to use that same athlete, let's take a five foot five inch, so that we're high right, 120 pound female bikini athlete being 10 to 12% body fat. So pretty average, right, four, five foot five athlete, you could be extremely competitive with those metrics. Now if we took that as an example, we have to convert everything back into centimeters for end kilograms for this equation. So let's start out by defining that, the height would convert to 165 centimeters, weight would be 54.4 kilogram and then skeletal muscle mass, if you're using an in body or a dexus scan for instance, you know, they have that percentage, right? When we look at the percentile of skeletal muscle relative to an average person, the age and height, this individual would be roughly 115% on an in body, for example, which tells me that their lean body mass would be approximately 49 kilograms or 108 pounds. Now when we plug all these numbers in, we're going to use both scenarios. Let's start with the cutting hem equation first. So we're calculating RMR and we're using that formula we mentioned earlier. And this example, it would be 500 plus 22 times 49 and that's going to equal 500 plus 1,078 that equals 1,578 kcal per day, right? That's what the cutting hem equation, factoring and muscle would equate to. So, you know, 15 to 1600 calorie a day is her resting metabolic rate. Now if we plug the same variables into the microphone's St. G. R, age-based equation, and I'm not going to read the full equation out because again, it's a very long equation. But you guys are more than welcome to follow along, plug those numbers in and it's going to net out 1264 kcal per day, right? Now to get to TDE, I'll just throw a footnote in there for you guys that may be our unfamiliar, so we're calculating the foundation number which is RMR, resting metabolic rate. To get to her actual color of needs, we then have to estimate the total daily energy expenditure. And to get there, we normally take RMR times an activity factor. And then activity factor is estimated based on their lifestyle, you know, are they a construction worker? Are they a nurse? Are they sedentary sitting at a desk for nine hours a day? And also, in addition to this, how much needs, so non-exercise activity thermogenesis, how much cardio, how much, you know, daily step count, things like this, all factor in. So, you know, you have to make reasonable estimate and the range is typically 1.2 to 2.0 for those multipliers. That brings you to TDE. And that's really the benchmark of what we would call like maintenance calories based on their lifestyle. And we would start to talk about, you know, surplus or deficit in calories from there. Now if you think back, these two versions of the calculation, the cunning ham coming up with 1578 cows versus 1264 cows in an age-based equation, that's about 314 calorie difference per day. Now think about that, right? This could severely impact performance or muscle retention. So over the course of a week, for example, that 314 cows adds up to around 2,200 calorie difference, which can impact your weight loss or weight gain anywhere from 0.75 to 1 pound per week. Right? So there's a significant difference in the two approaches here. And we want to make sure that for physique athletes, we have the most precise nutrition possible. Here's the one caveat that I'll throw into all of this because it almost sounds too good to be true, right? Hi everyone, coming up on this episode of Random Fit, myself Wendy Bats and co-host Ken Miller. We are going to talk about mobility matters. It's not just a buzzword. It is more than just flexibility. Ken, what are we going to discuss? We're going to talk about, like, so any, what is it? And more importantly, how do you get it and how do you keep it?
