So today on mobility matters, we're going to talk about what it really means. We're going to talk about this buzzword that we hear all the time. So Ken, I know you and I have talked a lot about this topic on our own, especially when it comes to our clients saying, hey, I want to move better, feel better. We're like, okay, we're going to work on your mobility and they're like exactly. So when you have a client, walks into the door and they say, okay, mobility, I want some, I need some. What do you say? I say, well, let's get some. You know, Wendy, and you have a good idea of my client, a big book of my client, teller, or business professionals, executives who are sitting behind a computer, they are on a plane, they're on a cross-country flight, they're jet setting, but they're in that fixed posture position. And one of the first things that comes up before we talk about mobility and being mobile is I feel stiff, right? So they tell you their condition, their state, and they're like, yeah, I feel stiff in the low back, my head, neck and shoulders, all of that is stiff. And then we talk about their goals and so what do you want to accomplish? Well, I want to feel more mobile. I need flexibility and I'll say to them, I go, well, let's, you know, let's talk about it. Let's talk about, well, what do we need to do to get you to feel less stiff and more mobile? So, and then we talk about, okay, well, what does it take and what are the steps and what are the stages to get unstiff and more mobile? So again, that's, that's usually how our conversation starts, but one of the first words that coincides with the word mobile is stiffness and feeling just rigid, word that comes up a lot of times too. So I just say, hey, you know what, you had mobility when you were younger, you did things to yourself and you do things every day right now that takes that away from you. So let's, let's get to work and this is what we're going to talk about today. Well, and it's interesting because I think it's important to define the difference between flexibility and mobility because they're really different, even though sometimes we use them in a way where it kind of makes them sound the same. So if you want to think about flexibility, we're talking about the passive range of motion and muscle can actually lengthen too, right? So we're thinking about flexibility. It's basically taking your leg and moving it into a stretch. We're trying to see how flexible that leg is, right? It only goes to a certain range of motion. We look at mobility itself. It's the usable range of motion that you can control. So you're passively doing it. Meaning that if I'm stretching your leg, can that's letting me see how much flexibility you have. But I just move my leg back on my own and I want to see what that joint allows me, you know, what, how far can I move that leg just on my own without help of, let's say, you or some practitioner or somebody else doing that. So it's really important because it lets me see on one end kind of what their limitations are. But under my own power, so myself moving it, I want to be able to see how much strain the coordination my leg can move and that lets me know more about their mobility. So there's a difference between someone pushing you and you being able to go to a certain point. And I think a lot of times when people are talking about being mobile, they're really just talking about being flexible. But one of my favorite things that I hear all the time is, oh, I'm super flexible or I'm hyper mobile. And I can do this that and the other. So what do you do about hyper mobility? And it's not necessarily hyper mobility that we're talking about. It's a term that we use or we hear that no one really talks about, which is relative flexibility. So Ken, you know, that I used to, in the day when I was younger, you know, I was doing this, right? So I could sit, I used to sit in the splits and do my homework. And people were like, oh, you're so flexible. And the thing is, it's just, I think if I'm sitting at the splits, right? My legs are out to the side and I'm just sitting there and I'm doing my homework. Think about what's happening at the opposite side of that joint. And at the time, I didn't care because it didn't matter, right? I really wanted to be super mobile or flexible. And I was only at a certain range of motion doing a certain thing. But if you watch the Olympics and you watch some of these gymnasts and you look at their posture and you look at that big arch in their back, if you had to, you know, if I said, define relative flexibility other than that, Ken, what is the definition of it? Well, I think the part of that is your body, you know, when you're going through a certain range of, like, if you're doing a task, right? So let's say it's me standing up in doing a toe touch. Well, let's say I can, I can reach down, touch my toes, but the question is, where am I getting that range of motion from? So a lot of people would think that, oh, yeah, well, you got good hamstring, extensibility, or your flexible through the hips. Well, what if my hamstrings and my glutes are a little tight and they're a little constricted? And I'm getting all that range of motion through my low back, right? That's, that's what we might call relative flexibility as that. You're actually taking range of motion where it's available because there's some place else that's not giving you that length or that extensibility. So you have to basically steal range of motion from another joint relative to a certain task. It's kind of like, or, you know, another one is where you do a peck stretch, right? You, you, you, you, you, you've got your, for our modern door jam, right? And you, you lean into it. But what, what, what people wind up doing and you can't see it if you're watching this. If my shoulder joint starts to pop forward, right? I'm not getting a stretch through the, the, the peck or the anterior shoulder. I've actually compensated my way by basically tilting and internally rotating through the shoulder for me to get my, my chest or my torso to rotate. So that basically we were based stealing from internal rotation for the sake of that lack of abduction. So I think it's really funny that you talk about wind be gymnasts because when I was the strength of the couch at Cal, one of the teams that I have was women's gymnastics. And I remember the first day that I told them, all right, the next stretch we're going to do, which I, I shouldn't have said it that I, when I think about, I should have phrased it a different way. We're going to do a kneeling hip flexor stretch and that's one of the things that, oh coach, I could do that. And what did they do Wendy? And again, great, great example of relative flexibility. They got on one knee, they were lunching forward and what did they do? There are backs where arched like a big reverse sea. So the intention of a hip flexor stretch for those of you that don't know is to get a little bit of length through the front of the hip, right? Well, what they were doing, they were a lot of them were tied enough through the front of the hip that they couldn't extend. So they had to steal a range of motion from that lower spine, that lumbar spine where they were now taking that lower spine and going into extension through the lower lumbar, right? So they weren't getting it through the front of the hip, they were stealing it from the back. So the first thing I did was I had to back them off, correct them by bringing their hips back. Let's work on a posterior tilt, squeeze the glutes, pull the belly button in towards the spine, and I'll tell you what, Wendy, 90% of them, just by repositioning their hip and making sure we got the range of motion from the front of the hip and we stopped stealing from the low back, right? A lot of them, they were done right there. They felt it. We didn't have to go any further. There was no lunging, just that little poster tilt, activation of the glutes and the lower core muscles and they were done. They felt it right there, just by addressing the component of relative flexibility because the low back was stealing the range of motion that the front hip didn't have. So that's my contribution to the sport of gymnastics. Well, and it's interesting because if you guys have ever taken gymnastics or seen a gymnast, that low back arch, unfortunately, is something that you're going to see often because the finishing you're finishing pose, if you will, you're trying to stick a landing, put your hands up and hold that position without moving because if you do move, you get points deducted, you want to stick the landing and hold that motion. And so they teach you if you feel like you're going to fall, if you kind of arch your back and hold yourself, sometimes that will actually help you keep your footing and help you control your balance, especially if you're coming off something such as the horse or whatever it is that you're doing with an excessive amount of force into a solid stop. And so because of that, the hip flexors do get shortened. So again, just kind of reiterate what Ken said when we're talking about relative flexibility, your joint or the muscles that surround the joint can only go to a certain extent because you're kind of borrowing then you're borrowing from another muscle if you will. He says, steel, I don't like to steal a lot of it because I return things. And so what we're trying to do when we're talking about mobility is get ideal range of motion throughout all of the proper joint. So therefore we're not borrowing motion from another joint because unfortunately that's when we start to see the compensation patterns. So Ken, you myself, I do this with Dr. Miller or Marty Miller on our other podcast one, talk a lot about, you know, on the Master Shark Around Table, talk a lot about assessments. The most important thing that we tried to determine when somebody walks through the door is how is the body moving? And if it's not moving with ideal range of motion at a joint compensation patterns are going to occur. And so if we see when somebody is squatting which is one of our major assessments that we do, we have some alif there hands over their head, they spread their feet shoulder to hip of the part, toes are forward and we have them squat down to chair height. Not how low can you go but just to chair height. If we see the feet going out or the knees moving in or different movement patterns in the low back meaning that they're arched or they're in like they have a rounded back, we note all of that because what's happening is there's a mobility issue or a strength issue. And so if we start to see that the feet start turning out as they go down, we know that but then if we do some ability testing meaning we have them, you know, kind of lunge forward with their toes two inches away from a wall and we see if they're knee can touch and their knee cannot touch then we know it's a mobility issue. There's an issue at the joint that's not allowing approximately 20 degrees of motion or not allowing the motion though. We want to the ankle so it's having to borrow from something else and that's what's bringing those feet out. However, on the other side of that if somebody did have their feet go out in that overhead squat when they were in motion but we had them do a mobility test and their knee could touch the wall without compensation. We know it's a strength issue on the other side and that's what we end up seeing. So when we're talking about these gymnasts that we're talking about, basically, just anyone in life that isn't moving ideally, we know that we know as a trainer what we need to work on is it flexibility, you know, getting better range of motion in a muscle because there's not an ideal length or is it a strength issue? So we know we need to do some some specific muscle activation on the opposite side so therefore it actually does its job and stops being lazy. And inevitably, someone's like, well, what about if I'm using doing a dip on a chair, if I'm doing the dip machine or a dip is a dip is a dip, right? Like if it, you know, what's the saying, practicing? If it quacks like a duck, walks like a duck, it's a duck. And yeah, so we're not against dips because we have no problem strengthening the triceps and, you know, obviously there is a chest involvement. But again, we're going to go back to the five kinetic chain checkpoints. And when you look primarily at the first joint that we're going to talk about is the shoulder or gleno-cumeral joint, that's a very mobile joint. So when we have joints that are mobile, inevitably, we have to give up some stability to have that mobile joint. So you have an anterior shoulder capsule, a post-tier shoulder capsule. The anterior shoulder capsule, which is sitting here in the front, which helps you prevent dislocations amongst other things. It keeps the head of the tumorous right where it needs to be to prevent impingements and all these other things. If it gets stretched out and becomes too lacks, it doesn't go back. Once you stretch it, that is, you know, what you're going to have. You're going to have a lacks or stretched anterior shoulder capsule. That's why so many people that have shoulder dislocations are highly susceptible to reoccurrences of dislocations because they've changed the structure within their shoulder. The post-tier shoulder capsule, on the other hand, is the one that's supposed to have a little more flexibility than what we tend to see in people. Shoulder tipping forward because the post-tier shoulder capsule can't receive the head of the humerus and the anterior shoulder capsule has been stretched out. So when you're seeing this gentleman in that position and again, any dip you want, you end up in this position. Under load, you're driving that head of the humerus into that shoulder capsule and basically forcefully stretching it under load. Yes, you'll work your triceps and yes, you can get some chest involvement, but we can talk about other exercises. But then also look where your head position has to go. You have to drive that head forward, which now creates more stress in the cervical spine, changes things that the SC joint, the AC joint. So there's a lot of risk there. And here's the amazing thing about the tricep. Is the tricep extends the shoulder, helps in shoulder tension. That's the only two things it can primarily do. So when people change hand grip positions and do all these variations, the tricep really doesn't care much except did you extend the elbow and did you help extend the shoulder? Those are your primary functions. So there's so many cool ways that we can do this without putting load into that anterior shoulder capsule and allowing the head to come forward. And if you really look up, if you inverted that gentleman and put his hands, you know, about chest level, it's almost a push-up position. So there again, you can do push-ups. You can do different variations of push-ups or we can get into all the different traditional tricep exercise we see with the rope and all these other fun things, stability, ball, skull, crush your skull, crush your countless, different things you can do without putting the stress on that shoulder. Now, you know, if you're in your 20s and 30s, you might be able to do these and be like, doesn't bother me. I'm 40s and I know a lot of people that are in that generation or higher. And all of the sudden, the years of training and or sports that altered their biomechanics, they start to feel it later on. So we're not saying that you have to feel it right now when you're doing it, just understand the load and stress that you're putting onto your structure. This primary, that being your cervical spine, and definitely your anterior shoulder capsule, but gain. That's just a question you have to have. And if you feel comfortable with it, then, obviously, you're going to try to get as much flexibility in the pack as much stabilization in the cervical spine, limit your range of motion, but even under those circumstances, there's more stress on that shoulder joint than other tricep exercises we could choose. And to piggyback off of that, think about too. There are a lot of the individuals that come into your gym and you do the assessments. They usually have internal rotation just based on life. And so you're also feeding into a very common compensation that by even doing this. Plus, I mean, this gentleman is doing it with his entire body weight. So that is a lot of weight. He's also putting on the stress of that shoulder capsule as well as activating the tricep. So there are, as Marty said, so many different alternatives that they could do in order to target the same muscle. Okay. === FILE: Using the Habit Loop to Break Old Habits [5GVPpdlkBF4].txt ===

Hey, welcome back. We make thousands of decisions day in and day out. And for most people who are making the same type of decisions and the same type of environment, these decisions are ultimately being handled from our fast-bring. They're automatic, based on years of learned patterns, and may also ultimately conflict with our goals. So what do we do if we have habits that we believe are problematic? You know, ones that ultimately have a negative impact and are keeping us or our clients stuck. Let's take a look at how we can use the four elements of the habit loop to unlearn a negative habit. Now, beginning with the queue, and an ideal environment, while you just remove that queue. But queues are complex. And they include time of day, they include people of mood, environment, and other behaviors. You can't always eliminate those. And you may be able to avoid them or alter them so that they remain within your control. Say, for example, your client complains that he is always overeating in the evening. And one of the reasons he overeats is because when he gets home from work, he eats the snack while he's making dinner. Now, if the queue is when I get home, then I grab a snack from the fridge. He may choose to come in through an entirely different door that doesn't land him into the kitchen. Or maybe he could decide to head to the bedroom and change clothes instead while he decides what he wants to make for dinner or what a healthier snack might be that doesn't necessarily compete with the dinner. When it comes to craving, this is the part that usually makes people give him to the old habits over and over again. They feel this craving coming on, right? Maybe it's a decision to rate the pantry or fridge, and that craving grows and grows and grows. It's as if that once your client recognizes you once to eat something, his brain won't crease the urgency and the intensity of that craving. And, to absolutely, it's so strong. So to change the craving, and this is really something that works with repeated use and practice over time, you can teach your clients to use a strategy that's called urge serving. If you think of your cravings or urges like an ocean wave, they will come on and they rapidly increase in size and impact. Now, when we think about an ocean wave, what happens when that ocean wave has reached its peak? It's going to break, right? And then it's going to begin to come back down. And the same is true for your client's cravings. On average, for most of us, it takes about 15 to 20 minutes before those cravings will go away. Now, depending on the habit, this could differ, and you know, sometimes it could be a little bit longer, maybe a little bit less. But the key is to remember that left on its own, the craving will eventually go away. The first time your client tries to resist that urge and surf the wave, it's going to feel pretty intense, because the brain is used to giving in and making that choice. The brain always says, oh man, I'm hungry, I'm going to open up the fridge. But eventually, with repeated practice, and the same, no, it gets easier. To recall that with COVID-19, there was so much talk about flattening the curve. Essentially, that is what we're talking about with urge surfing, and that's what urge surfing does. It keeps lowering the intensity of the urge until eventually it is so flat that really it doesn't really affect us. We can almost ignore it all together. So strategies for writing out the urge include waiting at 15 to 20 minutes before deciding if you want to give in. But you can also take advantage of distraction. No finding something else to do to write out that 15 to 20 minutes, maybe going for a walk. Or clients can also substitute a healthy option in its place. Maybe instead of writing the fridge in pantry for the high calorie and salty snacks, your client could opt for a piece of fruit instead. We'll talk more on snacking in the next video. Then to target the response, your client could increase the distance between himself and the high calorie snack that he tends to eat before and while making dinner. Maybe he only keeps healthy options in the house, so even when he does read the pantry, well, it doesn't do much damage. Or maybe he decides that he wants to move the tempting snacks to a far removed cabinet instead, or they'll be out of sight out of mind. And then lastly, to target the reward aspect, your client could find someone to help hold him accountable. Maybe that's you. And every night, he just sent you a text to let you know that he's successfully navigated that habit loop. Or maybe it's a spouser's partner who's kids. Now sharing these give up goals makes it that much more likely those old habits will be given up. We'll see you next time.

=== FILE: Using the Habit Loop to Create New, Positive Habits [7gUgOWha4ao].txt ===

Welcome back. So we've talked about the habit loop, fast and slow brain, and the power of identity and tiny habits. Now we're going to focus on how we can use the habit loop to consciously create positive habits. Let's work through an example. So we'll soon be client once to start a training program with you and help to work out first thing in the morning, three days a week. Let's walk through the habit loop to see how we can make it more likely that she consciously chooses this behavior and repeats it until it's habitual. Starting with the cue, the key is to make it something that occurs consistently. Now in the example, she is choosing to work out first thing in the morning, which actually makes it easy because really not many things are likely to get between her waking up and her response of going to the gym and training. So an easy strategy is to cue yourself if you're going to do and have your clients choose a behavior at any time of the day, is to find a statement where they are pairing their new behavior with something they always do. So creating a when I then I statement. When I do X, then I do Y. Or in this case it might look like when I wake up, then I work out. So have your client think about how they can tie the new behavior to something they're already doing and bonus points if it's something that they do consistently day in and day out. And for the craving, one of the things that's challenging is you've got to get a little bit more creative because you have to think of what will make your client crave something that she's currently not doing. Now one way to do this is to have her come up with a want to do activity and pair it with this need to do activity. So for example, if your client says, you know, I really want to be spending more time with my friends, maybe she can pair that with her new need to do behavior of working out in training. To crave the workout, she would combine her training sessions with you with that other activity of hanging out with her girlfriends and maybe sign up for group training. So in this example to crave her morning workouts, she signs up for group training with her friend, which makes her really look forward to her workouts even more and makes it much more likely to show a hold of yourself accountable and show up to train. Now let's talk about the response. This becomes really important because your client needs to make sure that the response that she's choosing is something she's likely to do. Now for this one, I usually have clients think of a scale of 0 to 10 with 0 being equal to no chance of doing that three sponsor behavior and 10 being like absolutely certain can knock it out of the park. You want your clients to choose a response that they can stick with 90% of the time or that they feel like there are nine times out of 10 going to make happen. When you talk to your client about training three days a week, maybe she says, yeah, absolutely. I can make that happen. I can commit to three days a week. But if your client came back and said, you know what, I only feel like I'm confidently able to do that seven times out of 10, then you'd want to look at what would make that number higher. Does she need to go to fewer training sessions per week? Does she need to make those training sessions shorter? You know, what would make her increase her confidence and make sure that she could absolutely do that response? Because we want them choosing behaviors that they're going to make likely to happen so that they can repeat them over and over again. And then finally, let's talk about the reward. How can you plan at reward herself for her new behavior? What immediate response can she include in her routine? No, it would make it feel like an absolute win. You know, for years when Chris and I ran, a woman's only fitness boot camp first thing in the morning, we had several women who would come to camp only because on the days they made it to their workout, they would stop with the coffee shop afterward to reward themselves for having gotten that exercise in. Have your client consider what she can use as reward for her efforts in order to make it much more like they stick with. Immediate rewards are best, but as long as she finds any behavior or any reward rewarding, and it does it compete with her ultimate outcome while then anything can really work here. By consciously thinking through the queue, the creating, response in the reward, your client can create support for her new behavior and increase the likelihood that she will keep on forming that behavior and repeating it until it forms a new habit. So the next time you or your client's have a habit that you want to work toward, consider how you can use those for elements to make it stick. See you next time.

There is the Paleo diet, the primal diet, the 3-day army diet. You know, so many out there, the intermittent fasting diet or protocol. What's the appeal of them? I mean, we see so many people who jump on, you know, this next phase or bandwagon of, okay, let me try this diet because they're looking for a quick fix. A lot of the times, I think, diets are glamorized. You know, either someone's promoting them or their popularized in popular media. Typically, they seem popular because they offer a short term solution. You know, if you do XYZ, you will get resolved by or resolved Z. And that's appealing to a lot of people. You know, we like some sort of solution to problems. And if a diet offers that, then it becomes appealing, you know, one of the things that diets offer are like a blueprint or a roadmap, which a lot of people like. You know, it's a simple, structuralized program that says, okay, if you do XYZ, you will be guaranteed these results. And a lot of times when people are looking to lose weight or to feel healthier, that's appealing to them. You know, there's this dichotomy between this is where I am. This is what the diet says. I will achieve if I follow these steps. And that's really popular. That's really appealing to a lot of people. So, eating that's one of the huge reasons about it. Is you do have this XYZ format where it seems to guarantee you results. You know, if you just follow these simple steps. I get it a lot with personal training and fitness where people want to ask me a question. And let's be honest, Vera, they don't like this answer, but it's a good answer from our perspective. And the answer is it depends. Right? So when they ask a question about fitness or they ask a question about nutrition, it depends comes from the place of education. Right? So there are different strokes for different folks. What are their different needs? What are different pathologies? What did your park use say? What did your input form say? What are your subjective and objectives? And science and what are your symptoms? There's so many things. And so when we say it depends, then people say, well, I don't want it depends. I want the answer. Right? And I think you're right with this. And then any diet is going to give you the answer. It eradicates the it depends situation and just says do it this way. Right? And people like that clarity, you know, as a dietitization when I counsel people or you know when my colleagues counsel people, there is a lot of it depends. You know, if we're asked, well, is saturated fat bad for me? Well, it depends. You know, how much are you eating? What else are you eating? What is the rest of your diet look like? There's no clear cut answer. And well, yes, it's bad or yes, it's good. And that ambiguity, it doesn't very sexy to a lot of people. You know, with with diets too, it's, you know, you can eat healthy. You can have a, if you're looking for weight loss, you can have a slower paced moderate rate of weight loss by improving the quality of your diet. But that doesn't sound that sexy. People don't want, you know, a prolonged change or a drawn out weight loss pattern. We want media results. You know, we're, we're, we're geared like that in our society. We want immediate change. So that concreteness, I think of a lot of popular diets tends to be very appealing. And you find that the majority of the diets, I mean, it's a, this is an underhand pitch question. The majority of the diets are pretty short-lived and why is that? Um, they are pretty short-lived. predominantly because most of them, and again, you know, I hate to generalize because they're different protocols in the different diets, but they typically cut out either a feed group or a significant chunk of calories or they have restrictive rules that, you know, you can follow them for like a month, a couple of months. But in the long term, it becomes difficult to sustain them. Um, you know, for example, if you're cutting out a huge food group going out to eat maybe death, I call it, not to mention that you may be a risk of certain nutrient deficiencies, depending on what the food group is. Um, but a lot of times, you know, the popular diets achieve their success by creating a caloric deficit, because someone who's looking to lose weight. If you cut out certain food groups, if you cut out huge portions of what you may have been eating before, then yes, you're now you're in a caloric deficit. So you are going to see some improvement. I will say some, you know, some popular diets will cut out things like a lot of processed foods that maybe, you know, high and fat sugar. That automatically is pulled on quote that I hate to use the term cleaning up your diet, but it does remove a lot of high calorie energy-dense foods that may have been contributing to someone's, you know, weight gain or to them not feeling so great. So if they cut that out, they're automatically going to feel better. Now you can do that without going on a diet, but having that structured roadmap, sometimes, you know, just seems appealing to a lot of people. I'm curious for those people who are going through nutrition, study and school and things like that. We all know the word diet just means what you eat. But in general, when we talk about diet, we, we're not talking about what you eat, we're talking almost about what you restrict. Right. So it's some sort of plan around your eating. In school, are they like, oh, I can't stand this or are they just like, hey, this is what it is and just understand it and let it go. You know, it's interesting because a lot of times when you even when you say the word diet, people automatically picture a like a clerical level or a clerical restriction that you should be eating. I'm hoping that going forward that schools, you know, even in popular media, the word diet doesn't take on such a negative connotation of restriction, but that it becomes more inclusive of, okay, what are you eating? What are your, you know, daily eating habits like? And I'm both as is more on quality versus getting into a numbers game necessarily and just going on and off a certain way of eating. I mean, in the long term, you know, going back to a question about why do diets, are they short-lived? A lot of them are short-lived because they don't bring about sustainable changes in your way of eating. I mean, a magic place or like the optimal place for someone to be in is for them to be able to fuel and nourish their body adequately and be comfortable modifying their diet in a variety of situations when they're traveling, if they're going out to a party, you know, if I don't know, wettings, whatever occasion, just being comfortable and knowing what they're eating is well within their nutrient, you know, needs. Being able to modify your diet in a variety of situations and being comfortable being able to do that is where we're ideally anyone really wants to be without having to yoyo on and off certain, you know, ways of eating and restricting nutrients. Well, one of the questions I have for you, I think this is probably the biggest thing when it comes to being someone that counts those people is not necessarily what is the right choice? Don't get me wrong. Yes, that is valuable and that's where that education comes in. But just because you know the right things, doesn't mean you can get people to do the right things. So what is the challenge for you as a registered dietitian that works with people to get people to try to increase their compliance and adherence to decisions or the conversations that you have with them? Great question. Multiple factors feed into people's decision, you know, to eat a certain way into their food choices. I think the environment we live in certainly has a role to play with the plekora of you know food choices around us. It's fast food, if you go into the grocery store, they're multiple, you know, varieties of things. And a lot of signs report that they they just feel overwhelmed with the amount, with the variety of choices out that they're not sure what to pick. Some clients report that they just feel compelled to eat, you know, dessert if it's in the house or they have, you know, a weakness for chips cookies candy and that if it's in the house, they're going to eat it. No, it's a fascinating topic. For anyone who's listening in, if you're throwing around this word macros, if you're not sure what it is, macros is just short from macronutrients, which are your proteins, fats, and carbs. In a lot of diets or in certain situations, people will count their macros, they'll count their grams of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins, because those three macros are the ones that provide calories. You don't get calories from vitamins, minerals or phytonutrients, but you do get calories from carbs, protein, and fats. And just as an FYI, carbohydrates provide four calories per gram, fats, provide nine calories per gram, protein per gram. So if you count your macros, back that one up again? fats provides nine calories per gram, and then proteins or what? Four? Okay, and carbohydrates or what? All right, all right, all right, contere. If you're counting them, it can give you an idea of your overall for a lower intake, but also how your calories are split up across protein, fats, and counting macros is a useful tool in certain situations. For example, if someone's looking to change their body composition, and they want to make sure that they're eating enough protein or enough carbohydrates to fuel their training, it can be a helpful tool in that case. Where I feel it's not so helpful is, you know, for the average person who's just trying to improve their diet, they can get very caught up in counting the numbers between, oh, you know, I need X number of grams of carbohydrate, X number of grams of fat, and start to eat just random foods in order to hit those macro targets, not paying attention to the quality of their diet. And by quality of diet, I mean, you know, are you getting a whole-in-process sources of lean protein of vegetables, of fruit, or full-rains of healthy fats? That, I think, should be in place before like an average person just starts to count their macros and worry about the numbers. So diet quality, I feel, for the general population, is superior to worrying about what your macros are.
